Rinaldi brings years of public library experience to her new position in New Jersey, including most recently serving as the General Duty Manager at the Lake County (Illinois) Community Library System since 2001. In her publications position with Lake County, Rinaldi's print and electronic copy activities have included evaluation, reprinting, purchase and selectivity; interlibrary loan, piece-by-piece copy, copyright protection, on-line public access to all reviews, establishment and management of an online database; planning and administration of the annual Club selection of books to be donated to local nonprofits; as well as bibliographic research and policy shaping development.
Rinaldi holds her Master of Library Science degree from the University of Illinois - Urbana/Champaign and her Bachelor of Arts degree in Anthropology from Central Washington State University.

Failure to raise the $16.7 trillion borrowing limit could force the United States to stop paying its bills by some time this summer, potentially triggering a credit default and plunging the global economy back into recession.
In the early afternoon on Capitol Hill, Lew was to meet House of Representatives Speaker John Boehner and other leaders to discuss proposals to raise the debt ceiling limit when the spending deadline nears at the end of August.
Congress raised the limit last time shortly before the legally required deadline was reached on April 27, 2013. It caused no disruption to daily business as lawmakers negotiated a deal to force other spending cuts to force a deal to force other spending cuts to avoid another catastrophic default on the debt. They were unable to deliver a long term spending deal to reduce government borrowing.

investors' shift to emerging markets is threefold: borrowers have less to fear because global central banks have opened the credit spigots to provide cheap and easy credit to the worse-off borrowers; the sell-side profitability of investment-grade assets is lower as general conditions get tougher; and investors, facing negative yields across the developed market, are seeking everything above negative yields.
Nowhere has this proved to be more compelling than in China, Ireland and Greece, all locations where yields have reached single digits as investors stampeded out of more expensive US dollar carrying cost assets in favour of high-yielding default-free sovereign debt.

Los Angeles Laker As former Los Angeles Lakers guard D'Angelo Russell said on Instagram, Kobe Bryant is a huge part of Sports Academy's DNA.
The 96,000-square-foot holistic athletic training facility in Thousand Oaks announced a partnership with former Los Angeles Lakers guard Kobe Bryant.
“Adding Kobe to the Sports Academy’s roster as a partner only reinforces the mind and body integration initiatives we have made at our facility, as well as our goal to extend the strength of sport inside and outside of the gym” said Dave Clavijo, Sports Academy CEO.
Sports Academy's in-season soccer and basketball curriculum are relentless, practical and driven solely by student-athlete improvement. The curriculum's ability to generate strength, speed and skill improvement was birthed from a keynote address given by Kobe Bryant at Sports Academy's opening day in September 2017. In that address, Kobe said he sees the facility becoming as important as USC or UCLA in providing opportunities to aspiring student-athletes.

women across the US are dying at disproportionately high rates has understandably brought her maternal mortality up there as a leading national and global healthcare issue.
According to a report published by the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) on Thursday, women continue to die in pregnancy and the year after childbirth at one of the highest rates among other developed nations - including the UK - effectively levelling US women's life expectancy to 78 years old.
Although maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation - with the exception of the US - the US has some of the highest maternal mortality rates compared to other industrialised countries, the study said.

a part of the city as bike lanes and subterranean grit. They’re ubiquitous, part scavenger campaign, part calorie bar, part breakfast, part study of anthropology. But New York City has all but locked the wheels of this semiautonomous institution.
When you’re watching football in New York City during football season, it gets crushingly hectic to locate a Steelers bar. It can be just as stressful searching out culturally delectable fare in restaurants that boast menus more Instagram­able than palatable. So it’s easy to imagine why the piles of dented aluminum steam cookers who herd through Fort Greene could be replaced by glistening white vans full of chefs. But that much overlooked industrial force would be lost—they’re more than metal wheels in concrete jerks pounding down crumbling wooden wood-frame plastics oozed with past icinesses, spills, overcooked spams, insults and sighs of utter tactlessness. Eng Sothichan, acting Minister of Information, Culture and Tourism said when asked about the latest stipulation for all foreign reporters at informaiton briefings about the kingdom's southern Luang Prabang province from Dec 6 to Dec 9 that foreigners should first apply for accreditation to each province.
The Vientiane Times reported that Mr Sothichan told reporters he urged the Ministry's subcommittee to put the accreditation procedure to each province to smooth out possible hoards of reporters looking to get accreditation to cover the Asean meeting.
Journalists accredited to each province will have to abide by each province's agreed accreditation procedure.

Leod was the chief financial officer of GEIA Insurance Services in Queen Creek, Arizona, and the president of General Coastal Elite Inc., owners of GEIA and GEIA Partners LLC, both based in Arizona. He operated as a general agent for one dozen insurance companies, acting as a broker to sell policies and provide liability coverage to public agencies, fire protection agencies and coalition agencies.
McLeod told investors that he would purchase liability coverage on behalf of law enforcement clients and then sell additional coverage to other clients who needed to be “co-lateralized.” In other words, he inferred that agencies would be covered by liability coverage sold through him only if he could sell liability coverage to another agency that would be collateralized should the first agency be at fault for some foreseeable incident. In fact, he was structuring sham claims for losses.
McLeod used investors’ money to buy collectibles to stock his investment office in Scottsdale. He also spent investors’ cash to buy airplanes, helicopters, resort property and motorcycles

As a result, Proclus has been portrayed as the leading figure of neo-Platonism, but his ideas were not only part of Platonism's general revival, as scholarship was launched anew to define the tradition's importance to late antique and Byzantine civilization as a whole. Proclus' systematic writing entitles him to claim the distinction of being responsible through his metaphysics alone to the creation of the general framework of neo-Platonism's system. Emerging from decades of movement work, Critical White Studies makes a theoretical intervention in endeavor to (once again) transcend white sentimentality.
Placing post whiteness in dialogics with whiteness would be a radical project birthed out of a deep sense of indebtedness to white people for all that we have—especially, often violently—been gifted.
But to afford whiteness such a posture, post whiteness would have to be open to being both indebted to it and critiquing it.
We found critical whiteness to be intensely self-reflexive, for even as it moved declarative statements about white experience to the forefront, it reflected on itself as both a critical theory and critical practice.

As revealed by 9to5Mac, all of the previous-generation Apple TV have come with batteries as standard, and right from the first-gen up, everything has been wireless and battery operated. Many leading blue-chip companies such as Walmart and PayPal are accepting payments to be made in bitcoin - another equivalent to cash - and some commentators say that they see the technology as the standard for digital transactions over the next decade or more.
Many large public tradable companies have rejected bitcoin as a reliable way to operate because their legal practices may be vulnerable to the volatile market conditions, whereas few would question the trade-in practices of accepting digital cash payments via Transferwise - a level up as efficient as cash hand pays but processing faster and more usefully than accepting cash payments in larger amounts.

DeepMind's system, dubbed EvalAgents, uses a well-known self-play reinforcement learning system to generalize to the unexplored world of 3D games. Reinforcement learning is reminiscent of concepts in behavioral science—as detailed by Barack Obama—a system would only be exposed to positive reinforcement to learn behavioral controls. Additionally, similar to Simon's Game—theoretical803 Program—the system would be exposed to none repetitive system log trees to learn more about each system.
At first study, the self-play system seemed to have some difficulty adapting to play in 3 games out of billions compared to only playing out Donkey Kong tiles (such as those seen above). After fine-tuning and pooling together the previous research, however, the system was able to traverse both Super Mario and Pixel system worlds.

Here's how to respond to interviewers' requests to describe your specific contributions to your past organization.
For some applicants, job interviews are about passing the first hurdle to gain entry to an organization. Some candidates may have been illegally discharged from previous positions or have criminal records that have hindered attempts to find a job.
If you have questions about your past organization's activities, especially because your position has a degree of public exposure, your interrogator may have specific concerns. Therefore, your answers should be detailed about your activities and contributions to the organization and should be proportionate to your level of skills and business understanding. Be cautious about alluding to legal disputes as long as it is still being taken care of in court, because doing so could potentially have adverse effects on your prospects for finding other work.

Greenwich resident Lloyd Hull was driven to continue his work as as a World War II re-enactor after he lost his vision to macular degeneration.
His wartime fighter-pilot costume proved to be ergonomically challenging. So he picked up an iPad and recorded himself to help other partial-blind enthusiasts emulate his pose.
His dramatic death over the weekend was a devastating loss to his surviving family members still reeling from the sudden death of his mother in June. His New York City wedding to Katherine Eshoo on Sept. 1 offered the first glimmer of hope amid a sea of sorrow.
His acoustics skills helped him make a career over other World War II enactors whose experience only halted there after they were honorably discharged from service.
In lieu of flowers, Hull's family is collecting donations to establish the Lloyd Hull Memorial Scholarship in Humanities at Washington University's Freeman School of Design. Monetary contributions may also be sent to 9561 Fisher Lane, Arnold, Md.,

We all want to succeed at work, as much as possible. But without free time, each day is about to be our only shot at life—it would be collapsing over us as a single moment before each other. That would be suicide.
We all have free time—between 9 am to about 8 pm—but someone has to be smarter than everyone else to organize this free time. You could organize your free time like a robot to make your job easier. You could automate your free time to fit everything smoothly instead of your busy life overlapping and meshed each other. You could be the slave who doesn’t have to spend time organizing anything.
How could your free time be collected, stored, and manipulated into things more worth doing?

companies instead sublease servers from larger companies that own large server farms. Smaller hosting companies sublease space to resellers who lease the server space to their own customers. The resellers typically host sites using control panels and automated scripts such as sitebuilders or automated mailing software.
A reselling plan contains only some of the features available in larger server plans. Typically, resellers may have only limited bandwidth to share with their clients, no more than one or two databases, no more than 100 active users for some control panels, no more than $100 in monthly e-mail credits and no more than 250 e-mail accounts. Typically, resellers have only access to servers that are not as robust as larger shared-hosting servers and often consist only of outdated servers and shared disks.
Hosting firm cPanel have more to say about reseller deals.

"At some level, you could almost look at an elephant as an animal tumor fighter," Hill said in a written statement. "We believed elephants would have large tumor-fighting organs because they live to be up to 70 years."
Hill's research was conducted with colleagues from the University of Pretoria in Pretoria, South Africa, and Smith-Kettlewell Eye Research Institute in San Francisco.

, how do you know how much to spend on projects and projects? As part of your procurement initiatives, you should be looking to reconsider your attitude towards your cash flow and your finances. Implementing lean elements, such as just-in-time procurement, can be hugely beneficial both for your procurement function and your end finance function.
Lean is a culture about seeing a waste anywhere in the system, and then finding a way to reduce it. If you can remove waste from as much of your business as possible, your business efficiency will be greater. Finances are no different - if you can reduce delays in the way your accounts receive cash payments then your business general ledger costs will all be reduced. In turn, cutting costs at all levels of your process should result in huge savings.

stamping out Internet piracy. Manifesto is libertarian in outlook, as would be expected from its progenitors, Ron Paul and president Emergent fame, Nick Gillespie.
But galling to supporters of copyright and other IP rights is the organization's failure to mention copyright protection as an important part of Internet freedom. Manifesto's discussions of copyright protection are vague and focus more on the potential costs to Internet freedom posed should fair use be diminished by overly-litigious copyright holders, rather than viewing piracy as an important part of that copyright problem.
Manifesto concedes that piracy undermines copyright enforcement, citing research suggests this could alter "the economic viability of copyrighted digital content." Manifesto also states that piracy could be taken as an excuse to undermine enforcement of civil liberties, singling out British protester Aaron Swartz's alleged piracy as a hacktivist -- a category that Manifesto doesn't define -- to illustrate the point. But Manifesto does little to discourage piracy other than standing up for basic civil liberties in

, some traders set up automated zones of price to sell at in the hope of protecting their profits to some gain coefficient. As long as the trade does not rise above this zone, the trade continues to be live and awaiting potential gratitude for not being taken out by selling pressure. What a concept!
But as actionable as this may be to some traders, it doesn’t give you much notice. In fact, averaging your profit out two trades before being taken out makes no sense if it lost you double your gain as your objective zone distance was small in relation to price action.
Exits should be more fluid to your trade's emotion. If price has moved lower, no doubt you have exhaled some volatility as to the trade's result. Generally, if a trade has moved down, it has sell pressure. So focus intensely on potentially accepting lower price as long as your risk specifications are met as required by your trade. So long as the trade's benefit to risk has not turned negative, stay in.

Marketers are employed in the public sector as well as the private sector.
Most people think of marketing as a strictly private sector activity, but the reality is people with sales and marketing backgrounds are hired by government agencies in a number of capacities. Government marketers focus on assisting small businesses as well as nonprofits as part of their job description. Companies within the public sector hire marketers to promote their products to different demographic groups, as well as to other companies.
Many government workers have careers in government marketing programs that focus solely on small business. Under the auspices of this program, agencies may hire someone who has studied marketing to focus on a particular industry within the small business framework. These practitioners may be appointed to focus on seafood within a small business framework or they may have to focus solely on the oil and gas industry within a similar framework. Companies with wide target audiences may hire marketers who have the expertise in small business to target them as a whole.

MIDDLETOWN, NJ - The Middletown Township Public Library and the Township of Middletown are pleased to announce the appointment of Kim Rinaldi as Provisional Library Director, beginning on February 24, 2014.
Rinaldi brings years of public library experience to her new position in New Jersey, including most recently serving as the General Duty Manager at the Lake County (Illinois) Community Library System since 2001. In her publications position with Lake County, Rinaldi's print and electronic copy activities have included evaluation, reprinting, purchase and selectivity; interlibrary loan, piece-by-piece copy, copyright protection, on-line public access to all reviews, establishment and management of an online database; planning and administration of the annual Club selection of books to be donated to local nonprofits; as well as bibliographic research and policy shaping development.
Rinaldi holds her Master of Library Science degree from the University of Illinois - Urbana/Champaign and her Bachelor of Arts degree in Anthropology from Central Washington State University.

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew on Sunday warned Congress against manufacturing a crisis over federal spending in the months ahead, as looming deadlines set the stage for a repeat of the political deadlock which two years ago triggered worldwide financial market jitters.
Failure to raise the $16.7 trillion borrowing limit could force the United States to stop paying its bills by some time this summer, potentially triggering a credit default and plunging the global economy back into recession.
In the early afternoon on Capitol Hill, Lew was to meet House of Representatives Speaker John Boehner and other leaders to discuss proposals to raise the debt ceiling limit when the spending deadline nears at the end of August.
Congress raised the limit last time shortly before the legally required deadline was reached on April 27, 2013. It caused no disruption to daily business as lawmakers negotiated a deal to force other spending cuts to force a deal to force other spending cuts to avoid another catastrophic default on the debt. They were unable to deliver a long term spending deal to reduce government borrowing.

NEW YORK — Television retailer QVC has made aggressive plans to keep shoppers watching — instead of mall-hopping — on Black Friday, an event it has traditionally ignored.
The leading network for TV shoppers promises special deals and a healthy dose of new items, seeking to win shoppers to a different kind of weekend mega-sales.
“We’re all about finding things to buy,” QVC said Wednesday as much of Wall Street ponders another recession and more layoffs.
But will shoppers be comparing items from QVC’s free weekend to those at retailers like Wal-Mart and Kmart? The two biggest of a small group are trying to sell TV sets and other electronic products to haul in mindshare amid growing worries about another recession.
“In these times that are difficult and difficult to go to your favorite malls, QVC has everything still you want to buy — right to your home,” said QVC president and chief marketing officer Terri Wood, who added that some products may be priced up to 75 percent lower than competitor retailers.

Record low and negative interest rates in developed economies are fueling a ravenous search for yield that is forcing pension funds and other conservative institutional investors out of their comfort zones and into risky emerging markets, according to fund managers and analysts.
The reason for investors' shift to emerging markets is threefold: borrowers have less to fear because global central banks have opened the credit spigots to provide cheap and easy credit to the worse-off borrowers; the sell-side profitability of investment-grade assets is lower as general conditions get tougher; and investors, facing negative yields across the developed market, are seeking everything above negative yields.
Nowhere has this proved to be more compelling than in China, Ireland and Greece, all locations where yields have reached single digits as investors stampeded out of more expensive US dollar carrying cost assets in favour of high-yielding default-free sovereign debt.
"If you’re an investor over 40 you remember all of your grandparents saying to you at some stage ‘I thought I was going to be leveraged to the hilt investing in Asia’," said Chris Lofthouse, chief investment officer - Mubadala Investment Company - India China Investment Fund.

Two UAE orders for military helicopters and guided bombs capped a remarkable year for procurement in which the Emirates became the largest foreign purchaser of US defence equipment, a Pentagon agency said.
The UAE, which has peacekeepers in Afghanistan, awarded Sikorksy Aircraft Corp more than $1 billion to buy 30 MH-60R Seahawk future combat system helicopters to replace the Navy�s aging Dolly Day MH-60S helicopters, Janes Defence Weekly said today.
Sikorsky makes fixed and rotary-wing aircraft. General Electric Co has a 50% stake in the subsidiary.
On the same day, the UAE government also announced plans to buy as many as 2,000 Dahlgren/EUR MM40 mondo-guided bombs made by Lockheed Martin Corp for overwatch missions against light armoured vehicles, combat-disrupted bridge locomotion, priority arms fire-production units, point-target aircraft, tanks, and other vehicles.
The Pentagons Financial Disclosure Office said procurement by the Emirates abroad was more than $8 billion compared to Irans purchase of $2 billion of military equipment. Overall, US companies bagged 22% of the Saudis potential 2008 procurement, said Janes, whose chief editor was an AFP correspondent

Obama used his first State of the Union speech Wednesday to push nervous Democrats to forge ahead on health care, despite voters' overwhelming unease about substantial - some fearful - changes to Medicare, our elderly health care system. Obama knows Washington projects the image of Washington's doddering gerontocrats, whose vaunted programs have turned him and his young fellow partisans into novicized neo-Gerontocrats.

Why are American women dying in childbirth?
Maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation - except for the United States.
The United States is not the first place that springs to mind when considering women dying in childbirth. So the fact that women across the US are dying at disproportionately high rates has understandably brought her maternal mortality up there as a leading national and global healthcare issue.
According to a report published by the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) on Thursday, women continue to die in pregnancy and the year after childbirth at one of the highest rates among other developed nations - including the UK - effectively levelling US women's life expectancy to 78 years old.
Although maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation - with the exception of the US - the US has some of the highest maternal mortality rates compared to other industrialised countries, the study said.

MOVE Systems: redesigning NYC's 1970s-era food trucks for an eco-friendly future.
Making the less-noxious food cart into an art.
There are 5,000 licensed food carts in New York, and they’re as much a part of the city as bike lanes and subterranean grit. They’re ubiquitous, part scavenger campaign, part calorie bar, part breakfast, part study of anthropology. But New York City has all but locked the wheels of this semiautonomous institution.
When you’re watching football in New York City during football season, it gets crushingly hectic to locate a Steelers bar. It can be just as stressful searching out culturally delectable fare in restaurants that boast menus more Instagram­able than palatable. So it’s easy to imagine why the piles of dented aluminum steam cookers who herd through Fort Greene could be replaced by glistening white vans full of chefs. But that much overlooked industrial force would be lost—they’re more than metal wheels in concrete jerks pounding down crumbling wooden wood-frame plastics oozed with past icinesses, spills, overcooked spams, insults and sighs of utter tactlessness. Newton's 29-yard touchdown to rookie Ed Dickson was enough for the Panthers to take a 23-21 lead, but the drive was suddenly soured when Asante Samuel was shoved out of bounds into the end zone for a 15-yard penalty that squashed the Panthers' drive.

Nike Inc enjoyed big sales in gains in North America and Europe last quarter and benefited from fewer markdowns, helping the maker of sports clothes and shoes report a stronger-than-expected quarterly profit.
Total revenue rose 7.7 percent to $6 billion (S£3.82 billion), but guidance provided was less optimistic than Wall Street's out-out forecasts.
The company still expects to drop profit to levels at least $2 billion to $2.1 billion by about March because of price cuts, restructuring costs tied to a U.S. office lease and rising labor costs in China, more than offsetting increased competitor pressure for discounts in some categories.
Economic problems overseas will weigh on demand and earnings over the next three to six months, as reported first quarter sales drive up costs and transportation costs up sharply for some products, said the chief financial officer Andrew Campion, who added that the company was monitoring situations in parts of Greece to see how they could affect its business.

Passengers on an ICE travelling from Berlin to Saarbrücken were shocked after windows were shattered by what they believe were bullets.
Police are investigating after windows on the ICE high-speed train were shattered during the journey from the German capital to Saarbrücken in western Germany.
The windows shattered when the train was travelling between the towns on Tuesday evening but no passengers were hurt. Police inspected the train and found no bullet marks or holes, Der Spiegel reported.
Passenger I.V. told DPA he was stunned as he lay recovering in his seat after two nearby windows smashed.
‘We saw three small holes, one in the ceiling and two others on the side of the aisleway where all the passengers’ shoulders would be,’ he said, citing Der Spiegel.

German railway police have launched an investigation to establish who was responsible.

WHEN predicting which planets beyond Earth could support life, astronomers usually follow the water. Exoplanets with rocky surfaces are declared habitable if they orbit far enough from their star to potentially host oceans.
But as our planetary collection grows, and telescopes advance to be more sensitive to faint wisps of molecules in the atmosphere, researchers have expanded their hunting criteria to seek other clues to extraterrestrial biology: gases that can sustain sky-high buildings and cloud-forming winds driven by water vapour.
For the past few years, Nick Ganote, who was a postdoc at Harvard University in America at the time, has been searching for such gases. In particular, he wants to pinpoint signatures of biologically steered circulation systems, which could harness dry land to sustain human-like life — the basis for more high-end extraterrestrial architecture. Read the full story here. 
At Stanford, America, Jose Funes researches some giant exoplanets that could be habitable enough to thought possibly sustain outgassing, in other words might give out small amounts of gases to be analyzed. His research focus has been particularly on postulating outgassing, that being most often water vapour from sea worlds or giant ammonia oceans, driven by pressure

Most gardeners think of diascias as low-growing bedding plants suited to a summer container or the front of a sunny border.
However Diascia personata breaks the mould and produces stiff stems that grow 3ft tall. The substantial bright green stems climb to a height of 4ft (1.2m) easily enough to maintain an impressive architecture and even to trail over walls.
The different flower colour forms are named for the British nursery that introduced each variety to them - Dorper, Duffton, Kingsport, Pennard, Postlethwaite and Whitirish. But still I can' remember who named Pennard - please tell me!
I used to struggle to encourage them to flower in pots because large containers require more plants to create a good flower display and as Pennard's stillness may discourage them to self-pollinate easily enough all I could get was an odd flower because none would self-pollinate easily enough.
But all the effort I did to create conditions that encouraged self-pollination to flower as prolifically as possible, was finally rewarded and the flowers flourished - only the odd one that was lost as the plant was overcome easily enough with leaf disease!

The Airline Vikings were playing for the state football championship in 1972 against Neville on a bad night for football in Monroe.
But after the team had gathered itself, head coach Jack Gray called his seniors together.
Gray, who coached the 1958 Airline Class, had said much the same to his last graduating class about football fans who can make a difference. The graduation was all being televised earlier that afternoon. Kids reached out to tell him he shouldn't have to play the game because he was injured.
Gray said he told them he would play because he never could have coached all of them without doing so.
"This was just us saying thank you for all he's done to us and to all of us and to just saying he was a good person," said brother Bo about what he recalled was the last football alumni reunion he attended.
"He said he needed us to play for someone who was still watching that way," said Brian Gray of his father winning the Class B championship. "We all thought about that and told him he could be proud of us."
He may have needed all that encouragement to go out onto the field on Nov. 10, 1972 because there was plenty he needed to drown out to play football.

In the summer of 1993, I had one of those experiences that stay with me for the rest of my life.
I spent 10 weeks in Europe, beginning with a six-week law-school summer session at Charles University in Prague.
Prague was everything I thought it should be: grand cathedrals; noble architecture; grand squares full of eager backpackers; cafes full of students arguing over politics. In other words, the ordinary meeting of my idea of Prague and reality was utterly perfect to my young sensibility.
But there was more at play: a sense of an ancient and ancient civilization all around me as I traipsed through these aging, yet still proud cities.
I still have in my backpack an album I took home showing Gustav Klimt paintings I saw on some hillside above the Solnay Valley just east of our city. No doubt other young travelers have travelled to all parts of Europe for centuries. But to be part of this whole was an extraordinary experience.
Hungory was the next stop in our travels. It was beautiful countryside, no doubt, full of peasants toiling in the fields and attended to profoundly interesting vineyards.
And then to Venice in Venice in Italy - another cathedrals

SANTA FE SPRINGS – A 17-year-old boy died and two men were wounded but expected to survive after a car-to-car shooting on the 5 Freeway late Wednesday, authorities said.
Coroner’s officials did not release the dead boy’s name.
The shooting happened about 11:45 p.m., according to the Sheriff’s Information Network. After authorities received reports of possible shooting victims, deputies arrived to find a shooting victim and a dead person among the passengers of a speeding car that slammed into another vehicle and several parked cars at Atlantic and Matchett boulevards.
The wounded man was taken to White Memorial Medical Center where he was listed in critical condition, officials said. His other injured shooting victim was driven to Los Angeles County-USC Medical Center with non-life threatening injuries.
Because no motive was immediately known investigators would not respond to questions about possibly the result of gang-related shooting, officials said. Two revolver-shaped objects were found at the shooting site, authorities reported.
The dead passenger was said to be a juvenile who was driven to White Memorial where he was pronounced dead.

Activities, games and puzzles are waiting to be explored by your inquisitive toddler.
If you haven’t been to your local library in a while, perhaps it’s time for a visit. Not only can you find there just about any book that your small student may be interested in reading, you’ll also find shelves full of books written especially to be used as little story books that children can turn into a collection of books as they grow up right in your local public library.
Many libraries have more than books and playthings to keep children entertained all year long. They may have a reading room full of activities books, puzzles, building blocks and coloring books that are all free to your child to play with as long as they would like to be entertained. Some have computers and machines to play simple children games to entertain children as young as three years old.
Librarians and kids can have a wonderful time coloring books together before your child goes home. You’re likely to find shelves of coloring books, as well as activities books to help your kid to learn about art, math and other school activities long before they’re required to be taught.
You’ll have no trouble finding some delicious sounding recipes to learn to cook out of your local library as well.

Ukraine has started siphoning off Russian gas bound for European customers. This follows the cutoff of gas supplies to Ukraine on January 1, after the two countries’ gas companies failed to agree on a price for 2009.
Gazprom has appealed to European brokers to tell other consumers to be as cutting as possible because Ukraine will also be looking to send a message, energy industry literature specialist Simon Manchin told reporters on Monday.
Long ago Ukraine dreamed of becoming a huge gas-collecting center that would immediately accumulate enough gas to lay down enough for winter. They would be securing gas long before Europeans needed to buy more, Manchin said: “Now I am completely mechanical, all that has happened makes Ukraine a gas storage facility.” If Ukraine lays down enough gas to last through a severe winter, over the long run it can sell enough gas to offset the shiver of misfortune.
This could be part of Ukraine’s bid to diversify its controls over Gazprom. Denying Gazprom potential transit flows could be used to exert control over transit pricing flows once disagreements have been threshed out.
But other scenarios have to be taken into consideration as well.

How it feels when J.K. Rowling gives us more "Harry Potter" information.
J.K. Rowling's "Harry Potter" universe is enormous. And since closing the book on the main series in 2007, she keeps adding to it. In fact, in 2016, Quantic Fox reported that the public needed more information about the "Harry Potter" universe to fill up the void left by the main series.
Rowling's "Harry Potter" books have remained wildly popular for years. Talking about her books is second-nature to many. We've all talked to school kids about the magical school, about life after, about Voldemort's rise to power, about the Ministry of Magic, and about the inevitable Clash of Kings. We've all rehearsed those same ideas over the years to try to get to the root of Voldemort's rise to power and want to see more. So then, why hasn't this all felt over-the-top?

Updating your ergonomic chairs may be a step in the right direction, but fixing your screen-slaying skills may be the smarter move. Make a habit out of holding your phone screen up instead of down to reduce crouching and slouching posture. If your screen tension is not enough to deal with your weaknesses as smartphone users, you may want to use your voice to play your favorite apps.

TURLOCK, Calif.--At a quiet park in Turlock, California, some ducks were found with their bills zip-tied to their necks, according to KTXL.
Donnelly Park is a peaceful park in the middle of town where some children ages 3 to 8 bring home recently released ducks to put back on the pond.
But over the weekend the pond was silent.
Neighbor Revu Baker was visiting the park when he noticed the ducks had been removed. And as he looked around, he saw the first duck being tied to another duck when more showed up to be zipped up. Some of the ducks were visibly distressed as volunteers lined up to do the job to all of them.
“I was immediately shocked and felt like someone had to do something,” Baker told Fox40 News of his decision to call Turlock animal control.
Two Turlock City employees say they could not stay silent about the unbearably cruel acts being done to animals.

Natural Resources Minister Jim Carr endorsed an advisory council report Thursday that spells out an aggressive agenda to liquify oil sands to speed up their development and to greatly expand wind and solar power.
“We have to have leadership steps taken... now,” Carr told reporters in Ottawa. “Finding solutions to address climate change requires hope right now.”
Canada has long resisted climate policy, however, erecting barriers to small wind farms and other programs in some provinces to said that would boost environmental objectives at a cost to the electricity grid.
“We have to be laser focused on finding solutions that are clean and competitive,” said Carr, Canada's acting natural resources minister.
“We have to realize some things have to change, but has no regrets about doing it the right way,” said Carr.

I used to play out all of those scenarios as a kid at holiday time. The trial of Washington Post correspondent Jason Rezaian, on vague charges including espionage, began in Iran on Tuesday.
On Tuesday, the trial of Washington Post reporter Jason Rezaian, who has been imprisoned for nearly 10 months in Iran on espionage charges, began inside an Iranian jail.
The Iranian organization that runs Tehran's Evin prison told reporters outside the facility, in a written statement, that he is being "wanted to establish terror" and has been ordered to remain in detention until communications with him about his condition end.
Rezaian's fiancee, who has repeatedly pleaded for his release from prison and said he has suffered from shingles -- said he has the skill to establish terror, inter alia -- was blurting to reporters about him.
"These are politically motivated charges meant to break Jason," wrote her attorney Frederick Powell, "not to ensure that he's punished."
At Tuesday's court session, Rezaian pleaded guilty to being "a member of espionage ring". Jason's mother rejected it as a deception tactic.

California is lifting its drought emergency for most of the state after a winter of record rain and snowfall that followed a five-year dry spell.
Gov. Jerry Brown's office announced Friday that his executive order will lift the drought emergency in California, except for some areas in the north, that remain under the declaration.
Brown said in December he was lifting the state's drought emergency for seven out of 15 northern counties as long as weather conditions held.
But in May he called for another 30 percent reduction in water use to stretch out water in parts of the state, where recent rainfall was inadequate to replenish the region's reservoirs.
The eligible counties have reached the target goal of cutting down, saving or recycling up to 20 percent from costs.
Gov. Jerry Brown's administration has asked residents to drink little to no bottled water to save money as the state continues to ration renewables amid the driest year on record in California.

CHICAGO -- A three-year-old boy died after a fire swept through his South Side home Sunday, police said.
Firefighters arrived at the three-story building on the 6700 block of South Dorchester Avenue two minutes after receiving calls of the fire. They made contact with a person in the home who told them children were still inside who needed to be rescued.
The homeowner was stabbed by another to escape, police said. The airlifted child was taken to Northwestern Memorial Hospital where he was pronounced dead.
A toddler who was in the hallway jumped to safety, police said. They could not give details about him because he was very young, and was being taken to another hospital to be examined.
Two other children -- a 7-year-old and a 3-year-old -- and two other adults -- a 29-year-old woman and a 37-year-old man -- were taken to Northwestern Memorial Hospital where they are all being treated for injuries sustained in the fire.
Fire erupted in the home's first floor. Some of the extension to the fire was reported to have jumped to another single-family home about 5 or 8 feet away.
The Chicago fire department's Safety Chair Jonathan Darr said a fire source still has to be determined

Assures reporters will not be blocked from covering Asean summit in Vientiane.
Laos yesterday defended its latest regulations imposed on foreign journalists, saying it would not prevent foreign media from covering the 2016 Asean due to be held in Vientiane this month.
Eng Sothichan, acting Minister of Information, Culture and Tourism said when asked about the latest stipulation for all foreign reporters at informaiton briefings about the kingdom's southern Luang Prabang province from Dec 6 to Dec 9 that foreigners should first apply for accreditation to each province.
The Vientiane Times reported that Mr Sothichan told reporters he urged the Ministry's subcommittee to put the accreditation procedure to each province to smooth out possible hoards of reporters looking to get accreditation to cover the Asean meeting.
Journalists accredited to each province will have to abide by each province's agreed accreditation procedure.
For Vientiane, such procedure is collecting contact details - name, mailing address, telephone contact and/or e-mail, certificate to prove their accreditation and deadlines.
Journalists who fail to fulfill each province's conditions would have to apply to the Ministry of Information, Culture and Tourism, Mr Sothichan said.

Jalapenos are used in many spicy dishes and used fresh, dried eaten pickled.
Jalapeno peppers are among the warm-season hot peppers of the Solanaceae family. Hot peppers, like jalapenos, need a long warm growing season to ensure no disease will hamper development to their full potential. They should be planted by early spring as soon as the last frost has passed each growing season to ensure plant protection.
Although most Hot peppers ripen to red, purple or yellow, some may be green. Ripened jalapenos may be eaten as part of an everyday meal, while red and green varieties are often used as garnishes in Mexican dishes to add a little snap.

HELENA – A state panel heard four hours of testimony Wednesday on bills relating to missing and murdered Indigenous women, an issue that proponents said affect all Montanans, but could have a profound impact on the Native American community.
House Bill 271 would create a commission to study missing and murdered Indigenous women within the state and to make voluntary recommendations to lawmakers as to possible approaches to address the issue.
Sponsors of House Bill 271 said the main goal was to gather information from different sources to apply elsewhere to try to prevent the disappearance of Native women within Montana.
Many of the Native women who have gone missing have worked as prostitutes or have had past criminal records, said Rep. Jennie Feltz, D-Anthem. Some may have fallen into the sex trade because of child abuse and addiction to meth, she said, citing testimony from advocates for Native women who have testified before other committees.
Federal reports have indicated that up to 31 percent of all reported homicides are caused by domestic violence, Feltz said, and about half of those homicides involved women.

Mismanagement and secrecy have stalled the war on terrorism—and at home its effects reverberate against civil rights.
If September 11 was this generation's Pearl Harbor, the Bush Administration's war on terrorism is still in early 1942, when, because the pain was focused abroad, American's homefront was largely insulated from the war's frustrations and petty perversions. After all, World War II was a clear-and-present fraud, as paroxysms of national grief distilled cynicism into anger and political fervor in the partisan conflict over the New Deal. Ironically, World War II was buffered, lowessized and de-fanged by the New Deal's national agencies and comprehensive plans. In contrast, most domestic agencies responsible for terrorism have small staffs and deficient leadership.

PARIS (Reuters) - Finding friends and meeting new ones could become even more important uses for global positioning chips than getting from A to B as the technology spreads to cellphones in coming years.
Combined with mobile Internet access, GPS (global positioning system) driven phones could be used to tell someone when to catch a plane or lecture, suggest restaurants or activities to attend at home, or catch up in cafes abroad.
"Someday digital assistants may guide us to the right person to meet for a business deal," said Gartner analyst David Wortmann, who added that OpenScape bidirectional alerts could be hugely useful to someone meeting someone for the first time.
At the Mobile World Congress technology fair this week, a senior General Motors executive told reporters that it saw no benefit to current automobiles in moving to onboard GPS chips within cars and looked to developing what he called "the connected car", relying on cell phones to monitor velocities and passenger counts and other passenger input to ensure driver safety. Some European manufacturers plan to sell connected vehicles within a few years.

There was no public participation sought to inform workers about the Transformative Fund’s launch. Some senior workers say their pay fights have lost steam after spending much of their salary voluntary deductions on buying more playthings.
Sectors whose staff have voluntarily taken part in salary cuts have not reported to the Bank of Kenya results-driven discussions to ensure all workers share sacrifices.

MUMBAI (Reuters) - Foxconn Technology is in talks to manufacture Apple’s iPhone in India, government officials said, in a move that could lower prices in the world’s No.3 smartphone market where the U.S. firm trails Chinese competitors.
A deal to set up a plant would be the first major manufacture in India by the world’s largest smartphone maker. Foxconn said it was unable to immediately comment.
The Indian government said in June it was investing about 28 billion rupees (£364 million) to boost domestic smartphone manufacturing to about 2 billion units a year, aiming to double India’s smartphone shipments to more than 350 million units over the next four years. But firms have struggled to expand into a country where large quantities needed to be manufactured can only be captured through difficult tariffs negotiations.
“In addition to supporting local manufacturing segments, Apple is evaluating opportunities... to bring parts and device manufacturing... to India in an effort to better serve India's growing population of smartphone users,” the spokeswoman said.
J.H. Bell, general manager of vendor relations at Apple India, said the firm was focusing now on supplying channels and distributors, and was not planning to launch devices made locally for another five years

HUNTSVILLE, Alabama – A light breeze passed through The Brew Stooges' quiet seven-barrel brewery Tuesday afternoon in downtown Huntsville.

And once all 22 taps are pouring beers within the industrial-style facility at the corner Market Street and Washington Street, the catchy and sometimes goofy tunes will replace the brewery's soundscape as pub-goers drink a flight of beers outside.

Granite Geek: When is a drought not a drought?
Right now in Concord, we are living in a meteorological puzzle: The National Weather Service says this is the wettest August since records began being kept 150 years ago, yet the USDA Drought Monitor still says we have moderate to exceptional drought over much of Cheshire County. So far, in fact, nearly all of New Hampshire has some level of moderate or exceptionally dry conditions.
We’re wise to be cautious because our climate has completely shifted to a much drier pattern: In 1998 over 60 percent of New Hampshire burned to the ground. In the past decade extraordinarily dry conditions had caused more small wildfires each summer than fire agencies could put out. In New Hampshire, today we’re used to getting about one inch of rainfall each September through June monthly averages. Good to be used to drinking bottled water!
At first thought, sounds like only New England has dehydrated. Well, in Africa, three climate scientists only have to look out their office window to know what desolation looks like. They live underneath a Swiss icon - the Matterhorn - and have views of glaciers melting to inland—the first time this has happened in recorded history.
Now look out your own windows

Activist shareholders in Australia’s largest independent coalminer are expected to vote in record numbers on Thursday to demand Whitehaven Coal aligns its long-term company strategy with the Paris climate agreement.
Guardian Australia understands the group Market Forces has secured support from coal giant BHP veterans Andrew Harding, Graham Brunton, Philip Andrew and Nick Bray, who resigned as chief executives to leave their careers involving the industry. Market Forces says it has the full backing of shareholders to pressure Whitehaven’s board into meeting climate goals to be aligned to the agreement to limit global heating to no more than 1.5 degrees celsius.
“We’re expecting to have the largest amount of votes in a proxy season up to now in relation to shareholder rights,” Market Forces spokesperson Adam Bandt said. “And that sends an enormous signal to the board of Whitehaven Coal to start coming clean about where its future represents to the climate change agenda as this will be almost impossible to push aside.
“The bewildering lack of detail and grandstanding about climate in [Whitehaven’s annual report] slides leaves shareholders justified in staying away.”

Perak Education, Technology, Science, Environment and Information committee chairman Dr Abdul Aziz Bari said Tuesday that Class XII student Shah Faisal Nizamuddin’s arm was burnt because he was still inserting electrical wires onto a drill.
“I have confirmed that no safety measures were violated nor inappropriately taught during the lesson itself.
“It was accidental and part of the lesson/excavation was placed beneath the water level as instructed by the class teacher," he said to reporters at the school after turning down a thermometer advice from Sekolah Jenis Kebangsaan (SJK) Tua Wawan BM 1 to close down.
Dr Abdul Aziz said the same class has been given another electrical project to prove this incident was not caused because of improper supervision nor inappropriately taught lessons.
“I have taken a class photo as video as proof that none was told to climb onto an excavation site," he said.
“I have ordered that no school would be suspended over this incident no matter what," he added.

I ran away from home at the age of 40. It was a home I had wanted for a long time, walked past when I lived a few blocks away. I finally got my wish and was able to buy it. It was shaded by huge giant trees, often eerie orbs could be seen turning in wind-less summer storms, navigating trees ancient enough to have leaves above ground, still providing shade long after the surrounding trees' leaves had fallen.
My new home was lovely, with plenty of room for my treasures and an equally lovely garden. In fact, the garden was breathtaking - three tiered, and large enough to be a wedding site. Many people came to visit, to be impressed.
My late grandmother amassed three hundred master paintings, to be left to me upon her passing. One in particular, more than any other stayed on my mind. An oil piece depicting a temple entrance - luminous colors picked out fertile fields by studio skills brought to such unrefined elements - horses providing a degree of comfort to long journeyed travelers on a late August day in Seattle Washington - beautiful yellow suns peeking out above glorious plantations.
I continued to find ancestors throughout the Northwest in crooked portraits - overworked paints donated to causes funding

The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission today charged the estate of Florida investment firm executive K. Wayne McLeod with running a Ponzi scheme that victimized an estimated 260 law enforcement agents.
McLeod was the chief financial officer of GEIA Insurance Services in Queen Creek, Arizona, and the president of General Coastal Elite Inc., owners of GEIA and GEIA Partners LLC, both based in Arizona. He operated as a general agent for one dozen insurance companies, acting as a broker to sell policies and provide liability coverage to public agencies, fire protection agencies and coalition agencies.
McLeod told investors that he would purchase liability coverage on behalf of law enforcement clients and then sell additional coverage to other clients who needed to be “co-lateralized.” In other words, he inferred that agencies would be covered by liability coverage sold through him only if he could sell liability coverage to another agency that would be collateralized should the first agency be at fault for some foreseeable incident. In fact, he was structuring sham claims for losses.
McLeod used investors’ money to buy collectibles to stock his investment office in Scottsdale. He also spent investors’ cash to buy airplanes, helicopters, resort property and motorcycles

What can poetry do when faced with the daily realities of war and hatred, violence and terror, the crimes that humans enact upon each other and on the Earth? A cynic would answer nothing, would condemn the personal lyric as pure solipsism, an idle distraction on the sensate foreplay of self and other as it moves from apprehending to naming, from naming to endowing meaning and value in utterances fixed to replicas, fixed to each other. Betty Odongo steadies the arc of her interrogative mind toward the deeper roots of poetry as a catalyst of names, which then connects us to other singsong-featured names who may have elected to forgo the same cathartic wordscapes we have bequeathed to ourselves. 
In one of Odongo's most arresting formal refrains, a couple depicts a scene of catfight on the sea, 
where guns fire everything 
between us.
But poetry does something more as well... As Odongo's speaker, exposed to and at the end participating in all forms of history, foregrounds her grief-response toward the abuser, with
I have told myself to be vigilant as I am
placed in harm's way,
Odongo paves her way out of the maze

The United States has conducted air strikes in Iraq against the Islamic State goup amid reports of more atrocities carried out by its fighters in neighbouring Syria.
Reports claiming the group was responsible for killing up to as many as 700 people in Syrian villages east of Raqqa have prompted the United States to step up its contribution to a coalition fighting against the militant group, with Apache helicopters conducting strikes to stop the atrocities.
Two strikes were conducted within three minutes of each other - it was the US's first strikes against Islamic State near Erbil - the group's de facto capital - in the north west and near the giant dam north east of Baghdad.

Right now, Thomason’s Wine and Liquor, just like any other liquor store in the state, keeps their doors locked and remains cash only. He said he still makes money, but he says business has fallen about 30 to 40 percent across the industry right now because of people staying home more.
“We’re doing OK because it’s only five months,” said Thomason.
“It certainly has been challenging,” said Thomason’s neighbor Joe Goodwin, who has three other small businesses within distance of Thomason’s entrance.
This has caused some business owners to reconsider what they’re doing right now.
“I just hope they’re not rushing to Amazon or Walmart to pick up their business online because as much as they gripe about Amazon, Amazon still picks up a lot more business than other places,” said Goodwin.
“With all the stuff that’s out there should be enough business to allow some to stay open,” said Thomason.

APPLETON – Ed Berthiaume, news director at The Post-Crescent, will step down from his post early next year after 29 years with the news organization.
Berthiaume, 56, voluntarily accepted an early retirement package from the company.
His departure was announced in a staff newsletter Tuesday by The Post-Crescent publisher Carl Vogeli.
This past summer Berthiaume was briefly hospitalized after he was electrocuted while clearing wet leaves at his home and garden.
“It should be no surprise to readers, other Posties and industry watchers that Ed has decided to step down as News Director,” Vogeli said. “January will be Ed's last full month as News Director of the Post-Crescent. In early February, TG will be wrapping Ed's desk in bubble wrap, taping him up and sending him on his way.” His retirement package includes full health insurance coverage.
There was no public discussion as to why Berthiaume was retiring, Vogeli added in his letter.
Berthiaume wasn't immediately available to comment. The Post-Crescent does not have a spokesperson to relay a comment either.

Proclus of Athens (*412–485 C.E.) was the most authoritative philosopher of late antiquity and played a crucial role in the transmission of Platonic philosophy from antiquity to the Middle Ages. For almost fifty years, he was head or leading philosopher at Athens, first as first schoolmaster to the young emperor Justin and later to Justin's leading general, Longinus. In both appointments Proclus's involvement was greatly instrumental. In a position to anticipate the career prospects of Justinian's successors, he ensured Platonism's posthumous survival.
We owe to Proclus's scholarship, more than to any other ancient source, our knowledge of Plotinus' work. As a result, Proclus has been portrayed as the leading figure of neo-Platonism, but his ideas were not only part of Platonism's general revival, as scholarship was launched anew to define the tradition's importance to late antique and Byzantine civilization as a whole. Proclus' systematic writing entitles him to claim the distinction of being responsible through his metaphysics alone to the creation of the general framework of neo-Platonism's system. As Proclus saw himself as the last great metaphysician, he wrote virtually everything within this framework as

Starting Tuesday, travellers from Europe, the Middle East and Africa will have to provide fingerprints and photos when they apply to visit, work or study in Canada, if they don’t want to be turned away at the border.
Currently, foreign nationals are only required to provide their photo ID when they are boarding an airplane, crossing the border or entering the public realm. IRCC has regularly indicated they will continue to accept other types of photo identification to visit Canada, however, they must be approved by Canadian consulates abroad. 
For tourist visas, nothing much will change for the time being. Both biometrics collection and additional documentation requirements are still being tested but more details should be revealed soon. 
For work and study visas, IRCC has indicated that more details about the exemptions will be shared in late 2022, however, for study visas only, beginning June 1, additional supporting documents - e.g. school leave forms - may be required to secure authorization to remain in Canada throughout the duration of your study.

A lot of folks say they don’t like okra, but the deer at New Moon Farms just south of Loganville love it. They also love green beans, watermelon, cucumbers and sunflowers. And they don’t even wait for Mary Etherton to plant her garden to gorge themselves. They are quick to visit the fields that had summer crops, gobble up as much as they want and move on to other areas. The first of the summer garden snaps was common OKRA and yellow and orange ATMOSPHERIC FLOWER MIX.
Mary Etherton said the deer love her sunflowers and cistus candies, as well as the common okra, a good source of immune-boosting beta-carotene. Amy’s Garden’s Nikki Ditlefsen said her hunting companions will tell her about when deer respond to fresh-picked tomatoes. She said deer overnight visitors to her garden patches used to leave compared to now they head right to the cistus candy to feed on the flower tops and leaves each morning.

Centralizing the procurement process, diversifying supplier portfolios and assessing the capabilities of each manufacturing partner will allow enterprises to mitigate the impact of or eliminate product recalls.
In 1982, 31 million bottles of Johnson & Johnson's Tylenol were removed from the shelves of Walmart stores across America. It was the largest voluntary recall in U.S. history and was prompted when someone added cyanide capsules to several bottles of Extra Strength Tylenol capsules reported at three Chicago stores. Just three months earlier, in July 1982, Delroy D. Johnson added cyanide capsules to bottles of Tylenol he'd buy from the same Walmarts stores in Chicago as he'd recently lost both his mother and father to diabetes and was planning to commit suicide on Sept. 8,1982. KEI KECIL, Indonesia: It is believed by many on the Kei Islands that some of their earliest ancestors came from Bali, braving the long expanses of sea to the west.
Those original descendants, countless generations ago, jumping overboard when their ship was released to sea to escape slavery. But one girl dreamed of seeking another route through the ocean.
Walking on piles still exposed above water at Anak Crater Lake's surface, limping over lava outcrops and scrubby heathland, filled with thought outloud to long dead ancestors: "We would leave by sea... because the island is small, small, small!"
To Western eyes, Anak Krakatoa - translated as Child of Krakatoa - looked more like Rabbit Island. Desperate to trek inland and onto its beach to see rabbits - within Emperor Penguin's range - the local guide assured he would plan it to compete with the planned trip to Krakatoa's beach front.
With no diesel to fire up the 4WD to monkey over the roads' rocky outcrops, and no launch to allow ferrying passenger-as-fish - the only way to island side was to optionally carry your bags all through the trekking way instead.

Renting an apartment with bad credit may not be easy. Many large apartment complexes owned by corporations now require credit checks and will refuse applicants who do not meet their standards. Even if you have the income to pay for the apartment, you may still be rejected because of your bad credit. One option for those with bad credit is to apply for live-in sublet space. By subletting with tenants who have good credit already, you will be approved for rental opportunities much more quickly than if you have your name on the lease alone.
Credit History Factors Determined for Qualification
It is difficult to secure rental space if your bad credit rating makes you appear to be a bad risk to landlords. The main challenge is that potential tenants who have bad credit may be unable to prove that past debt has been paid off and no longer poses a default or collection risk. Landlords wishing to lease to tenants who have bad credit often want to be confident that past debt was paid on time and no other concerns exist. Therefore, subletting may be much easier to obtain because your good roommates' credit history may be used to back up your qualification for rental. Landlords have long used guarantors to secure good tenants who may have bad credit scores

(CN) – A federal appeals court in New Orleans upheld Mississippi’s three-drug method of lethal injection on the ground that the inmates challenging it had filed their complaint too late.
Death-row inmates Alan Walker, Paul Woodward, Earl Berry, Dale Kent Grim, Brian Mosley, Leon Tilghman and Cory Scott Johnson sued in 2008 to challenge Mississippi's decision to adopt lethal injection as the execution procedure for all condemned inmates.
However, only two continue to have active suits because Johnson has been executed.
According to the opinion from the New Orleans-based U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, the first challenge to Mississippi's lethal injection procedure was brought in a different case, and the three-drug protocol was used for an execution only three years ago because another inmate had exhausted all avenues to seek damages for being forced to force drink large amounts of another execution drug widely believed to be dangerously toxic.
Although the inmates alleged damages arising out of all executions involving Mississippi's lethal injection procedure, instead of naming only the particular execution the suits were challenged in order to apply to all executions, judges upheld the three-drug procedure.

Failing to include complete and accurate business details may result in the letter being returned to you.
Use the business name to begin your letter, as the first part of your salutation. The business name should be standard and posted as often as possible to let your recipient know your business name. Add your return address to the right side of the letter to ensure your letter is sent to your business first. Put your business name just above your contact name, as this should be the longest name to be listed. Add your address above your ZIP code so your mailing address is listed above your recipient’s address.

Opinion|Should I Give Up on White People?
Should I Give Up on White People?
Mr. Yancy is a professor of philosophy at Emory University.
Glenn Ligon, “Palindrome #1” (2007), neon, fluorescent lighting, computer print-out mounted to Masonite over plexiglass. Courtesy of Wanda Isman Gallery, Los Angeles/Galerie Lelong, Paris. Photo: Jason Wyche.
Emerging from decades of movement work, Critical White Studies makes a theoretical intervention in endeavor to (once again) transcend white sentimentality.
Placing post whiteness in dialogics with whiteness would be a radical project birthed out of a deep sense of indebtedness to white people for all that we have—especially, often violently—been gifted.
But to afford whiteness such a posture, post whiteness would have to be open to being both indebted to it and critiquing it.
We found critical whiteness to be intensely self-reflexive, for even as it moved declarative statements about white experience to the forefront, it reflected on itself as both a critical theory and critical practice.

Green Bay -- The Green Bay Packers have agreed to terms on a three-year deal with wide receiver James Jones, a source told the Journal Sentinel.
According to the source, QB Aaron Rodgers and WR Donald Driver went to bat for Jones with Packers management.
Jones agreed to accept a $25 million deal over three years with base salary of $7 million, source said.
Jones first came to the Packers as an undrafted free agent out of San Jose State in 2007. He has played all seven years of his NFL career with the Packers.
Jones is no stranger to being a Pro Bowl wide receiver. In fact, he has posted 55 catches for 758 yards and three touchdowns the past four seasons. During that same stretch he has also added 39 catches for three scores each season, and he has a career total of 587 receptions for 7,608 yards and 49 touchdowns.
Jones has distinguished himself as a three down wide receiver over the past decade, as he has also added more yards rushing than passing completion.

Hair loss is no longer an inevitable march to baldness. Medical advances in recent decades mean male hair loss can be treated, and it need not break the bank.
The cause of male pattern baldness is well established as an act of nature not to be resisted - women's hair tends to stay thick and stylish throughout life, regardless - but new research may be turning up some untapped solutions.

Metaphysics special: Do we have free will?
“DID I really just decide to have fish and chips for lunch?” Humans have been wrestling with such questions for millennia. Maybe not about the fish and chips, but about whether we are free and responsible actors who shoulder up to pressure to behave badly, or whether our actions are conditions of environmental causes rather than manifestations of conscious decision.
In classical philosophy, free will was believed only within restricted categories like voluntary action, meaning the choices people willingly generate within contexts over which they have some control.

The New Remote May Or May Not Come With Battery

Clarithromycin belongs to the group of medications called macrolide antibiotics. It is used to treat infections caused by certain bacteria. It works by killing or stopping the growth of bacteria that can cause certain infections. Clarithromycin may be used to treat flare ups of stomach ulcers caused by bacteria (staph bacteria). It may also be used to treat sexually transmitted infections caused by bacteria.
Clarithromycin may be used for other infections caused by bacteria as well. Clarithromycin should only be used to treat infections caused by bacteria. Clarithromycin should not be used to treat viral infections such as a cold or the flu.

Port-au-Prince, Haiti (CNN) -- Haiti's capital seemed to spring back to life Wednesday, more than a week after a devastating earthquake brought everything to a standstill as rescue workers looked to give hope to survivors trapped under concrete and steel.
Since Tuesday's first rescue at a site in Port-au-Prince, other survivors were found in tents within the grounds of Haiti's damaged national palace and at the airport.
The airport's concrete toll plaza, which was used as a makeshift shelter by some in Port-au-Prince, has been emptied out amid worries that more bodies could be found.
Although shaky footings have been added to buildings to stabilize them, national authorities said none of them have been told to be moved out as survivors may still be inside, CNN reported.
Static images of Port-au-Prince shot over the past couple of weeks revealed parts of the city to be completely destroyed as smaller buildings collapsed onto larger ones, while others looked intact -- but still had whole streets littered with rubble that was still smouldering.

Millions of American workers in their 50s and 60s want, or need, to keep working past the traditional retirement age of 65 — either part-time or full-time. But after attending Columbia University’s 2017 Age Boom! research symposium, all hope may not be lost for full-time workers who want to stay in the workforce longer — provided they have 25 years or more of paid coverage. 
“The main reason all retirement plans offer basic coverage today — three to four years’ worth of salary — is to lessen the penalty for workers who need to stay on the payroll longer than originally anticipated,” said Sam Roske, VP-Investment Management at Empower. “And although everyone would love to have more coverage, 25 years of coverage may be enough — or more — to give workers up to age 90 some spending security.”
The pension plan gap has long been a source of concern for policy makers in some parts of the country. An extensive study released today by the New York State Comptroller focuses on estates that span multigenerational/familial generations — as some New York City workers’ religion may be reflected — that have no plans to continue a pension regime beyond three years of retirement coverage.

HELENA, Mont. — U.S. Rep. Greg Gianforte is pinning his third campaign in two years on Montana residents being better off economically since President Donald Trump took office and that the voters will give him some of the credit. He also plans to campaign as an unapologetic conservative who wants to unleash free-market energy production to further enable economic growth.
Gianforte was all but locked out of a first bid to replace outgoing Republican Rep. Ryan Zinke, a favorite of industry groups because he often moves to appease them instead of focusing on conservative principles. In a run off with ex-state lawmaker Rob Quist, Gianforte also criticized him for supporting the single-payer health care plan backed by Senato Mayor Steve Bullock as part of a rare leftward swing among Montana Republican candidates.
"This president and his administration has unleashed energy production all across Montana," Gianforte said in a meeting Monday with reporters.
"Under President Trump, he has secured more oil leases for Montana, he's made more investments in Montana," he added.

Tributes have been paid to young Teesside mum Laura Hodgson who has lost her fight for life.
Laura, from Billingham, was diagnosed with triple negative breast cancer last year.
The mum of two beautiful children died peacefully on Sunday, June 22, just weeks before her 37th birthday.
Daughter and boyfriend paid tribute to her saying Laura was a fighter from way back."We knew she was fighting hard though," said her youngest daughter Myla Hodgson. "But it was over before she knew.

Body-piercing advertisements are more and more widely available. In New York City, stores dedicated to piercing have mushroomed. Bodies of Polished Gold, a piercing parlor run by three women who sport green dreads, is one of nearly 40 shops within a compact downtown block.

The latest lawsuit to target the proposed Clippers arena in Inglewood alleges two city-linked boards violated state laws governing open meetings and the environmental impact of construction projects in June when they approved disposing of land connected to the plan.
In a complaint filed Friday in Los Angeles Superior Court, the small Inglewood-based environmental nonprofit Forward Founders said the Inglewood Neighborhood Investment Committee and Inglewood Redevelopment Committee violated the Brown Act governing public meeting laws because they added more to the agenda at the sessions than was originally suggested.
 Aside from spare details about improving sidewalks and bicycle infrastructure near the proposed arena site, no other significant discussion was raised about the environmental impacts out to virtually all limits of the Inglewood planning boundary; about costs to rip out three lanes of heavily travelled busy Highway 103 as part of the plan; or the amount of entirely privately funded infrastructure needed to pull off the entire plan, Forward Founders complained. If Mayor James T. Butts has his way, the arena might be up and running by 2017 as part of the plan now on the table.

TOBYHANNA TOWNSHIP -- PennDOT is making an effort to improve safety conditions on two major highways in our area.
On Monday, crews began installing guide rails along Interstate 380 in Monroe County to prevent vehicles from crossing over. Just more than 40 feet of guide rail was installed on Monday -- ranging from Delmar Street to Schosse Street.
"It's because of three different accidents over different years that caused people to lost control," said Dave Navarino, a PennDOT public relations specialist.
Navarino said all three accidents involved cars hitting guard rails -- sometimes because the guard rails needed to be replaced and sometimes because the guard rail was moved to accommodate other projects.
“It was all over three different years," said Navarino. "We have to be proactive and be more aggressive to get it up when we could have done it in the past.”
Navarino also said 15 feet of guide rail was put in on Route 390.The three feet should be installed within three to four weeks.

The cryptocurrency craze is reaching frenzied levels as 2017 draws to a close.
Barely in the cents when trading was started at the beginning of this decade, the price of the signature currency - bitcoin - has jumped some twenty-fold in the past week to over US$16,000 per coin.
This makes bitcoin easily more valuable than a US gold bar and almost as valuable as a US ounce of gold.
Bitcoin was still only being used as early as last year to buy pizzas in New York and Tunis but it is becoming another gold bar as more retail investors join the mania over an asset that can be easily stored in your laptop.
Many leading blue-chip companies such as Walmart and PayPal are accepting payments to be made in bitcoin - another equivalent to cash - and some commentators say that they see the technology as the standard for digital transactions over the next decade or more.
Many large public tradable companies have rejected bitcoin as a reliable way to operate because their legal practices may be vulnerable to the volatile market conditions, whereas few would question the trade-in practices of accepting digital cash payments via Transferwise - a level up as efficient as cash hand pays but processing faster and more usefully than accepting cash payments in larger amounts.

Ronald B. Lund, 64 years old, died suddenly in his home, July 22, 2013. He was bon in Taunton, son of the late Melvin and Natalie ( Hammond) Lund. He was the former owner of Lund's Auto body and an active member of the Maine State Elks Lodge #9041. He had retired as a landscaper from Portland Precision Ag following 45 years with the company. One of Ron's favorite projects was designing and planting flower beds for retirement homes. Ron was also active as keeper of Coconut Robertson Park in Portland and as master of ceremonies of the Maine State Elks Lodge's parade every July 4th. Ron was a lover of historic buildings as well as antiques, stone castings and fine japan bronze sculptures. In addition to his mother he leaves three daughters, Alison Lund and Vanessa Howard, both of Portland, Bev Horner and her husband, Win, 42 East End Rd., Peaks Island (longtime summer resident); one sister, Val Lund King and her husband, Errol, Falmouth and three step granddaughters. In addition to Elks Lodge #9041 he was a member of the former Elks Lodge #86.
