Police say a Hopedale man made it very easy for an officer to arrest him Wednesday he handed paperwork to the traffic cop that said his license had been suspended.
Nykolas Karl Rosenberger, 20, was arrested after the 4 p.m. traffic stop on East Park Street just north of East Main Street.
Rosenberger told the officer he could drive to Boston because his license was suspended.
“I told him no he couldn’t because he could be arrested for driving with a suspended license,” said Officer Phil Guite.
Rosenberger was found with a baggie of marijuana and additional cash, Guite said. He arrested him for driving on a suspended license, carrying marijuana around 2 ounces, and for additional cash on person.
“We have a good working relationship here,” Guite said, referring to the Hopedale police chief. Guite said he knows him from other agencies he has worked for.
Rosenberger was released on an improper vehicle registration, and he was being held on $550 bail at the Worcester County Sheriff’s office. It was unknown Tuesday night if he has hired a public defender. His court date was listed as Sept. 30.

LONDON (ICIS)--Italy-headquartered energy group Eni is readying its Ravenna plant for a 50% capacity expansion during maintenance in August, a company source said on Tuesday.
The Ravenna site on the Adriatic coast, which now has some 800,000 tonnes/year of propylene derivaite outputs, has an existing planned limit facility brought onstream in September 2013, to produce 172,000 tonnes/year of propylene derivatives.
In mid-July this year, Revema decided to double its propylene, glycol aldehyde and dimethoxy to produce paraxylene, said the source who was not authorised to speak to the media.
Production of 350,000 tonnes may start immediately on completion of the first phase of the project by the first quarter of 2020, with full ramp up to be realised by the third quarter of the same year.
The facility would be connected to Eni's polyethylene and polypropylene plants being constructed on site, as well as to the Parsoro plant for paraxylene, he added. Exploitation would be carried out for at least seven years to reduce costs, he said.
For more on propylene visit ICIS

Google's artificial-intelligence researchers at DeepMind have developed a new algorithm that improves its game-play capabilities.
After mastering dozens of 2D Atari games, and whopping humans at Go, Google's DeepMind artificial intelligence (AI) is now taking on the more difficult challenge of three-dimensional gaming worlds.
For some perspective—one of the first games that DeepMind mastered was Asteroids—but today, the artificial intelligence taken all the way down to the system root log level.
DeepMind's system, dubbed EvalAgents, uses a well-known self-play reinforcement learning system to generalize to the unexplored world of 3D games. Reinforcement learning is reminiscent of concepts in behavioral science—as detailed by Barack Obama—a system would only be exposed to positive reinforcement to learn behavioral controls. Additionally, similar to Simon's Game—theoretical803 Program—the system would be exposed to none repetitive system log trees to learn more about each system.
At first study, the self-play system seemed to have some difficulty adapting to play in 3 games out of billions compared to only playing out Donkey Kong tiles (such as those seen above). After fine-tuning and pooling together the previous research, however, the system was able to traverse both Super Mario and Pixel system worlds.

Learning how to answer tough interview questions can help you get the job you want.
Interview questions that ask you what you will contribute to the company are designed to help employers weed out the best applicants. Your answer to this kind of question should demonstrate that you have detailed knowledge about the organization as well as your enthusiasm about being part of its continued development.
Here's how to respond to interviewers' requests to describe your specific contributions to your past organization.
For some applicants, job interviews are about passing the first hurdle to gain entry to an organization. Some candidates may have been illegally discharged from previous positions or have criminal records that have hindered attempts to find a job.
If you have questions about your past organization's activities, especially because your position has a degree of public exposure, your interrogator may have specific concerns. Therefore, your answers should be detailed about your activities and contributions to the organization and should be proportionate to your level of skills and business understanding. Be cautious about alluding to legal disputes as long as it is still being taken care of in court, because doing so could potentially have adverse effects on your prospects for finding other work.

Lloyd Hull, seen here in 2014 with a D-Day shell casing fired from the USS Laffey, was a beloved Greenwich resident. His family is paying tribute to him with a concert in his memory from the London Philharmonic Orchestra.
Greenwich resident Lloyd Hull was driven to continue his work as as a World War II re-enactor after he lost his vision to macular degeneration.
His wartime fighter-pilot costume proved to be ergonomically challenging. So he picked up an iPad and recorded himself to help other partial-blind enthusiasts emulate his pose.
His dramatic death over the weekend was a devastating loss to his surviving family members still reeling from the sudden death of his mother in June. His New York City wedding to Katherine Eshoo on Sept. 1 offered the first glimmer of hope amid a sea of sorrow.
His acoustics skills helped him make a career over other World War II enactors whose experience only halted there after they were honorably discharged from service.

A judge wrote that Chicago has shown a ‘‘likelihood of success’’ in its arguments that Attorney General Jeff Sessions overstepped his authority with the requirements.
CHICAGO — Attorney General Jeff Sessions can’t follow through — at least for now — on statements he made virtually two years ago about stepping up enforcement of federal lobbying laws, a Chicago judge said Tuesday.
U.S District Judge Thomas M. Durkin wrote that Chicago has shown a “likelihood of success” in its arguments that Sessions overstepped his authority by citing the Illinois congressman whose office was serving as counsel to the Chicago Board of Wholesale Trade to stop alleged bid-rigging.
Session’s decision to cite Ald. Edward Burke and impose campaign-finance charges was odd because Chicago was the only state that had used public funds to hire outside legal counsel, according to the city’s lawsuit.
But Sessions has said he believes he has the right to fine or even imprison public officials who violate federal laws. And a White House spokesman said Sessions has said he wouldn’t cite a lawmaker to validate his decision to step up enforcement of federal campaign laws.
Sessions said he wanted to make clear he was stepping up enforcement.
And he told reporters he felt free to use his enforcement powers to combat bid rigging

Lincoln Chafee is running for the Democratic nomination for president in 2016. He served one four-year term as Rhode Island's governor, beginning on Jan. 4, 2011. He was the first Independent to be elected Governor of the State of Rhode Island. On Dec. 22, 2006, he beat out three candidates to win the general election; he was finally elected one year later by a margin of just over 4,000 votes. He has two previous runs for the White House as part of the Reform Party. In January of 2008, he won the Reform Party's Iowa Straw vote. In August of that same year, he finished in third place, garnering 13,091 votes in New Hampshire. In 2003 he was elected to fill the void in the Senate left by Ed Stack, who resigned when he was convicted on corruption charges in Rhode Island's Providence Turnpike scandal. Chafee had first won a seat in the United States Senate in the Republican Primary election in August of 1992 as part of the Allan D. Hughes campaign against Senator Claiborne Pell. BANGKOK – The preliminary rites of the coronation of the new King Vajiralongkorn of Thailand, who ascended to the throne in October 2017 after the death of his father King Bhumibo, kicked off Monday.
King Vajiralongkorn, 66, was then crowned as King Rama X in the spectacular ceremonies that are believed to have taken place over several weeks.
King Vajiralongkorn replaced King Bhumibo, who ruled the Southeast Asian nation from 2008 to 2017.
King Bhumibo was King Rama IX who surpassed his father King Prajadhipok (Rama VII) to be the longest reigning king in third place according to Guinness World Records.
According to him only King Mongkut (Rama IV) and King Chula Ngorn (Rama V) surpassed him as he celebrated his 70th birthday on Dec. 28.

Walter Chen is the founder and CEO of iDoneThis, the easiest way to share and celebrate what you get done at work, every day. On his downtime, he blogs about management, entrepreneurship, and happiness on the iDoneThis blog.
We all want to succeed at work, as much as possible. But without free time, each day is about to be our only shot at life—it would be collapsing over us as a single moment before each other. That would be suicide.
We all have free time—between 9 am to about 8 pm—but someone has to be smarter than everyone else to organize this free time. You could organize your free time like a robot to make your job easier. You could automate your free time to fit everything smoothly instead of your busy life overlapping and meshed each other. You could be the slave who doesn’t have to spend time organizing anything.
How could your free time be collected, stored, and manipulated into things more worth doing?
Your free time shouldn’t be like your actual life at all—it should be about to be crafted into your happiness. So today we are going to brainstorm ideas for no-work-free-time done checklist: ideas to organize your free time to be more easily to be

It’s been almost eight years since the last recession ended in June 2009, Steve Rick, CUNA Mutual Group chief economist, explained in an interview with HousingWire.
With economists predicting the next two years won’t bring a recession, Rick noted the past eight years has been volatile and has brought about some adjustments to the way things will be effective over the next few years.
It's taken awhile to get things normalize in terms of stagnation, he said.
“It may be tougher out there than would have been originally thought two years out, so it may take some time for that to work out,” Rick said. 
But despite concerns a recession could be looming down the line, he said problems have felt closer to the surface lately because unemployment has gone down more than 1%.

A legally blind Ormond Beach man was attempting to wash dishes Tuesday evening when his father yelled and spit at him for not cleaning them right because of his blindness, an official said.
A legally blind Ormond Beach man was attempting to wash dishes Tuesday evening when his father yelled at him for spilling a glass on the floor because he couldn’t clean them right because he was legally blind, an official said.
John Herbert of Ormond Beach could be fined up to $1,000 and has to attend a public service lecture onSection 768.131 of the Florida Statutes: Battery or Aggravated Battery, the court said.
According to court documents, Herbert was visiting his dad's house to play video games when he said he noticed some fluid underneath his father's feet.
Upon inquiry, he said his father asked him to move out of the way because he, Herbert, was creating a mess, charging documents stated.
Herbert indicated to New Smyrna Beach police officers that as he was attending to his father he accidentally knocked over a wine glass onto the linoleum floor.
His father, Gordon Herbert — whoalso has committed felony domestic battery in the past— responded tothe incident by spitting on Herbert's face and yelling over him

NEW DELHI: Over fifteen years after the Concorde — the world’s first and only supersonic aircraft to be used commercially — retired, US aerospace major Boeing has announced it is working on the next-gen aircraft that will be able to go faster than the speed of sound.
Boeing plans to launch a joint research project to study aerospace technologies & potential safety concerns to ensure supersonic flight could be viable within two decades.
Seattle-headquartered Boeing has been developing AS3X (Anti-Sonic Spike eXploitation) system to potentially reduce “overpressure blister”, break up noise that occurs when subsonic aircraft fly near metropolitan areas without supersonic noise disadvantage.
“We’re talking to representatives from Europe about possibilities with a joint research effort to potentially study aerospace technologies and potential safety concerns to ensure supersonic flight could be viable within two decades,” he said while elaborating about the plans to deal with overpressure blister when planes travel over populated regions.
Supersonic flights could potentially happen much quicker after overcoming technical barriers regarding noise and other environmental concerns.
The plan would be to fly at supersonic speeds over an oceanic region to ensure passengers with no ill-effect. The planes don’t fly over mountains because vibrations tend to hammer passengers during takeoffs

BOSTON (AP) — An Amtrak employee suffered an apparent heart attack and later died after a train struck a piece of construction equipment near where he was working early Thursday morning, officials said.
The Albany, N.Y.-to-Boston Lake Shore limited struck the piece of machinery about 8:25 a.m. in Carlisle, located about 35 miles north of Boston, said Massachusetts Department of Transportation spokesman James Daly. The incident happened about two minutes after the train left South Acton Station bound for New Rochelle, N.Y., he said.
The incident caused the train to derail as another train headed to New York City slammed into its side, Daly said. Investigators said both sides have killed investigators believe the wreck was caused by the sudden braking and force sent the machinery to fly into the side of train.
“Track workers were finding parts inside the railroad passenger facility,” he said.
Work was initially underway about 3,000 feet north of the crash site before tracks leading north to New York City was taken out of operation about 2 p.m. Tuesday to replace several bearings on track bridges there. Officials said the crossing was closed to help facilitate the work.

Dawn Of Planet Of The Apes opens in UK cinemas on June 16th.

Stamford's Old Town Hall Redevelopment Agency this week chose Nov. 19 for the opening ceremony for the renovated Old Town Hall building.
Both Mayor Dannel Malloy and the new mayor elected that week are expected to be in attendance. Republican John Harkins has said he expects to be sworn in as mayor June 12 but has been unavailable to be interviewed about who will be in attendance.
Nov. 19 is World AIDS Day, an important national holiday to the Stamford Gay & Lesbian Affairs Commission whose children's program will be heavily involved in the grand opening ceremonies.
Speakers are expected to include Mayor Dannel Malloy and City Council member JoAnne Damiani.
The celebration runs from 2 to 4 p.m., at the Old Town Hall, whose doors have been repaired and exterior painting has been completed. Some of the historic charm has been restored by texturing the ceiling and lighting fixtures.

The long wait for Tesla's new Model 3 is almost over.
Tesla (TSLA) CEO Elon Musk will unveil the company's first car for the masses Thursday night. Tesla fans who can't afford the Model S, which costs between $80,000 and $100,000, have eagerly waited to learn more about the somewhat lower-end cousin as expensive projects threaten to rip up cash spigots.
Tesla has not officially released pricing information for the car, citing China as part of the reason for the delay, but competitors have said the Model 3 could come in at less than $50,000 -- a goal sought to gin up possible pink slips from Washington D.C., who had threatened to upend domestic auto deals because of the high cost of some of Tesla's products, The New York Times reported Tuesday.
Some have claimed the pricing could end up more than $45,000, which could derail Tesla plans to sell 500,000 cars annually by 2020. If they do sell at lower price points, however, Tesla's chief rival, General Motors (GM), could be at risk -- losing its vaunted spot as America's largest automaker because of the lack of opportunities to sell 500,000 cars

Sentenced: Maurice Hennegan, 25, was sentenced to 32 years to life in prision for murdering a man who was romantically involved with Hennegan’s estranged girlfriend.
A Bedford-Stuyvesant man will spend more than three decades in prison for fatally shooting a man who was romantically involved with his estranged girlfriend.
Maurice Hennegan was convicted Oct. 15 of murder in the shooting death of Jarobar Montgomery at Fresh Pond Mall in East Elmhurst.
Hennegan was immediately sentenced to 32 years to life in prison at the proceedings in Queens Criminal Court.
“It was a senseless murder,” District Attorney Melinda Katz told reporters outside the courtroom.
Isaac Monge told jurors he witnessed Montgomery’s murder.
He said he was shot in the right arm as he was about to punch Hennegan over Montgomery’s affair.
“I was jumped. They thought I was the other guy Dwight Montgomery,” Monge testified.
Jurors also heard testimony from another witness who said he saw Hennegan firing a gun in Montgomery’s direction as he lay dead on the ground.
Evitt Bell was driving Montgomery to get a shoebox that was lost at Woodside Municipal Court, Bell said.

Business, medical, construction and development interests have poured money into the gubernatorial campaign of Republican Robert Bentley, while labor unions and PACs that received contributions from gambling have been a major source of cash for the campaign of Democrat Ron Sparks.
An analysis released today of campaign spending reveals $15 million was reported to the coordinated campaign treasury, the joint bank account controlled by all candidates and committees parties may establish to raise money without being personally vulnerable, in the first half of this campaign—42 percent from business and other public interests, and 38 percent from gambling business.
The $15 million total reported to the Joint Campaign Committee for the first half also is greater than all of the spending reported for each of the past three general election campaigns. Campaign spending in each of 2006, 2008 and 2010 was limited to about $1 million by an agreement to reduce campaign spending because of fund inadequacy.
“It is clear that spending has grown faster than contributions, driven largely by expenditures to develop campaigns,” said William Martel, Vice President of Fairly Fair Money in Elections who wrote an analysis of campaign spending and contributions. Some independent experts say DNA testing is inadequate for analyzing botanical products.
ALBANY, N.Y. — DNA barcoding has exposed some infamous cases of food fraud, like cheap catfish sold as pricey grouper and expensive "sheep's milk" cheese made from mixed ingredients - products sold because manufacturers mislabeled assets, perhaps to reduce costs or to circumvent cholesterol concerns.
DNA barcoding keeps another kind of adulteration from creeping past the salesman's office counter. Different species often blend their leaves and berries - for example, leaves from aster's flowerheads sometimes blend into the underside of dandelion's leaves and resemble the genuine dandelion leaves used as garnish -- or chewed or swallowed as tea.
At the New York State Agricultural Experiment Station, one system involves mostly natural products. Integrative Pest Management Technologies LLC, near Geneva, is proving to be about 98 percent successful in using smears of plant leaf surfaces extracted with tape to check bayberry, ironweed, partridgeberry, thistles and other botanicals. The tests help maintain good quality controls because consumers have become suspicious about dyes used to disguise products' color. The US economy “remains strong”, the Federal Reserve chairman, Jerome Powell, told Congress on Tuesday as he signaled the central bank is on course to carry on gradually increasing interest rates in the coming months.
In his first congressional testimony since his appointment as Fed chief three months ago, Powell said he still believed the US had enough strength in its labour market to withstand any potential headwinds to the economy as unemployment remained historically low.
The president may have only said nine more words during his State of the Union address, which was dominated by Democratic victories to expand national healthcare coverage, partisan tirades about immigration and promises to have America “win again”, Mr Froomkin wrote.
“In light of developing conditions”, he said definitively — as he often does spontaneously in his public statements, providing no devilish details about the Fed’s plan to raise rates as expected — the Fed would continue to move steadily towards its goal of three more increases to rates this year, at least five after that and as many as seven to nine more by the end of 2021.
But he said he thought the Fed would be right to change policies if conditions continued to deteriorate because “it’s more important to us that economic conditions stay right” than keeping unemployment down

A message in a bottle that washed up more than 108 years after it was thrown into the sea may be the world's oldest, a marine association has said.
The bottle was released in the North Sea between 1904 and 1906 by Edwin F. Pennell of Lunenberg, Nova Scotia.
It was found about 25km off of the east coast of Canada's Nova Scotia, by Hans-Johan Horner, of Kristiansand, Norway.
Since none of Mr Horner's relatives used the word Pelika Maria, and as most children do not carry names suggested by elderly grandparents or other relatives, the researcher assumed it belonged to a woman who was more than 100 years old - and so probably to a dead person.
But DNA tests showing it belongs to a likely specimen described as "a steep-spirited puffback -- greyish brown above... somewhat longer tails... good enough specimens" to be included as specimens explicrated as of the type -- as in the sense used in scientific monographs -- have helped establish the creature in the records as a new Canadian specimen for Quebec from the north-upstream part of New York State.

Dear Amy: My college-age nephew confided in me that he is gay.
I was very surprised. I am OK with his sexuality. It was good to hear about him in a less formal way because he moved out of town for school.
He told me he has told no one, including most of his family. And he has not told his father, a minister.
He is struggling more with the dearth of relationships with other gay men than with who knows about him. His point was being out to family is difficult enough as it is. So he's hoping to stay single because he believes being out would be more difficult for him than being single would to his father.
Is this realistic? Do you suggest he come out to his father, believing he has friends who could intercede for him or forgive him, should he be rejected? -- Caught Off Guard

Reseller hosting businesses rent backend server space from larger companies.
2 Can You Make Money Being a Web-hosting Reseller?
Web hosting companies earn money by selling server space to individuals and businesses. While some hosting companies own their own servers, many companies instead sublease servers from larger companies that own large server farms. Smaller hosting companies sublease space to resellers who lease the server space to their own customers. The resellers typically host sites using control panels and automated scripts such as sitebuilders or automated mailing software.
A reselling plan contains only some of the features available in larger server plans. Typically, resellers may have only limited bandwidth to share with their clients, no more than one or two databases, no more than 100 active users for some control panels, no more than $100 in monthly e-mail credits and no more than 250 e-mail accounts. Typically, resellers have only access to servers that are not as robust as larger shared-hosting servers and often consist only of outdated servers and shared disks.
Hosting firm cPanel have more to say about reseller deals.

New data released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows there were 1,014 stillbirths in Montana in 2018 — an improvement of over 20 percent compared to 2013. In all three categories examined — ex utero newborn deaths, stillbirths and first-year neonatal deaths — Montana still maintains some of the highest rates in the country.

(CNN) — Elephants are giant, cancer-battling super creatures that destroy damaged cells long before they become cancerous, scientists say.
In a study released this week, scientists said elephant genes may provide a crucial clue in the fight against malignant tumors in humans, as well as other animals.
Elephants have huge lungs and oversized tissues that replace damaged cells faster than in any other mammal, meaning they deal with disease more effectively and may live longer, said Dr. Steven Hill, the study's senior author and assistant professor of oral biology at the University of Minnesota, Minneapolis.
"At some level, you could almost look at an elephant as an animal tumor fighter," Hill said in a written statement. "We believed elephants would have large tumor-fighting organs because they live to be up to 70 years."
Hill's research was conducted with colleagues from the University of Pretoria in Pretoria, South Africa, and Smith-Kettlewell Eye Research Institute in San Francisco.
Elephants may have tumor-fighting enzymes, Hill said in a written statement. Plus, they have especially large stomachs that house elephant cells that also fight tumor cells.
"These cells have giant nuclei containing copies of up to 164 elephant genes," Hill said. "

BOSTON – A disgraced former state chemist may have tainted more prosecutions than officials had first estimated, an independent reviewer of narcotics cases said Tuesday.
More than 40,000 defendants may have been affected by the chemist's mishandling of hundreds of cases in addition to more than 21,000 defendants whose convictions have since been overturned, attorney General Martha Coakley's appointed reviewer said Tuesday.
Lab head Anjeanette Drexel resigned over a dispute over her continued employment amid questions about her management of drugs seized by police that may never have been tested to allow them to be used as evidence.
With Drexel out, Governor Deval Patrick appointed Supervisor of Crime Laboratory Gerry deRoche to replace her pending implementation of defensive audit procedures.
Coakley and deRoche have said more than 21,000 cases have been reversed as part of an agreement to handle toxicology driver's license checks separately from other cases.
But on Tuesday, Louis Fischi said the agreement doesn't release Drexel's office completely from possible wrongdoing because other tests may have been overlooked unnecessarily because of other mixups.

Yogis may be enjoying a surprising benefit when they unroll their mats and strike a pose. A new study finds that just 20 minutes of hatha yoga stimulates brain function.
Researchers from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign enlisted 15 study participants to take one hour-long class six times over four weeks.
At the end of each session, study volunteers were given tests for focus, verbal memory and reading accuracy.
Scientists discovered that after the first study class, participants could remember more images from the previous session compared to the baseline memory tests they took beforehand. They observed no improvement in memory function after subsequent study sessions.
On its website, the Critical Thinking Coalition details the research subjects as being “expert level” in critical thinking skills, reading and focus, and unlike previous studies, the critical-thinking skills of the volunteers improved slightly more each class.
“We are interested in developing more critical thought as part of everyday life activities like baking, studying or sorting laundry. Flipping on the TV to escape life feels increasingly alluring to some of us as the years pass,” study author Dr. Dominique Polosky told Health News in a quote. Polosky directs research with the Pediatric Neuropsychology Clinic at the Carle Illini Table

New analysis shows 22 of Australia’s largest companies are actively working to undermine the Paris agreement targets, betting shareholders’ money on strategies that assume global climate change action fails.
Investor action group Market Forces says those companies – worth a combined $121 billion in market value – have proved fiscally vulnerable to disclosing risks to capital as they pledge to expand production and “address” climate risk through climate initiatives dubbed “Net-Zero Asset Managers”.
Market Forces spokesperson James Whalley said the evidence was clear: If Australia does not move to net-zero emissions within the next decade, the large companies in Australia would be unable to be supported by investors seeking to reduce their asset exposure to climate climate risk.
“The large Australian companies all have plans to clean up their pollution. What we saw was very much plans to clean up their pollution that rely heavily on being supported by investors who want to reduce exposure to climate risk,” Whalley said. “We have large companies in Australia saying climate change is very important to them but these companies want investors to continue to provide money into their business as long as possible.”

Composting is the ultimate win-win-win for gardeners.
It is recycling at its most basic, turning yard and kitchen waste into rich, organic planting material. It saves money on fertilizer and pesticides. It keeps earthworms working and off the purchase list. You’ll probably have fun along the way.
Before you begin to plan your garden for the season, devote some time and effort to your choice of compost piles and arrangements. Soil preparation should help provide the advantage of compost quickly, as basalt/non-bark mulch chips expensive to use as chips get compacted from foot traffic and other things.
What to do depends on four factors: Where your garden yard waste will be stored, What your yard waste is, Who has access to it, and What foul-smelling smells you want to deal with.
As to Where your waste/piles can be stored, your garden has to be taken care of first. If you only have a small garden, this is not difficult. If you have a larger garden, yard waste has to be kept some distance away from your garden beds each season.

Home Procurement News Why is lean accounting necessary in the supply chain?
Why is lean accounting necessary in the supply chain?
Knowing how to manage your finances is important for any business. If you aren't sure how much money you have in your accounts, how do you know how much to spend on projects and projects? As part of your procurement initiatives, you should be looking to reconsider your attitude towards your cash flow and your finances. Implementing lean elements, such as just-in-time procurement, can be hugely beneficial both for your procurement function and your end finance function.
Lean is a culture about seeing a waste anywhere in the system, and then finding a way to reduce it. If you can remove waste from as much of your business as possible, your business efficiency will be greater. Finances are no different - if you can reduce delays in the way your accounts receive cash payments then your business general ledger costs will all be reduced. In turn, cutting costs at all levels of your process should result in huge savings.
How can we achieve better procurement-financial integration?

It takes a lot to make me feel ashamed of London, my beloved home city. But yesterday’s tower-block inferno did it. The raging fire at Grenfell Tower in North Kensington, the disturbing speed with which this home to hundreds was reduced to ashes, and the shock at how buildings within such easy distance of the BBC office and Westminster have revealed the shocking state of our housing laws, was utterly horrifying.
Hundreds remain missing as the London tower fire continues. Children have died. Bodies are still being removed from the rubble.
Let’s imagine you’re Gina Carter. You buy a new piece of luxury real estate in a block commissioned by a third party developer who controls who has a freebie apartment to live in.
Now imagine another piece of luxury real estate. This is your relatively grand old Victorian flat in, say, Highgate. You bought this at auction, from a private seller whose self-improvement was more about currying greater social cachet rather than generating cash to reinvest into the community.
Now imagine some act strikes at random and indiscriminately kills hundreds. It could be a disease, terrorism, an outbreak of violent communism – who knows? In each case the only certainty is that your apartment would have to be emptied.

The customer may not always be right. What are some circumstances where they could be wrong?
In a recent trip to a grocery store, I grabbed my usual few items in a hand basket and was about to SCURRISE up the register aisle amid packs of other busy shoppers when suddenly I realized that it would be more efficient to turn down that aisle to another express cashier instead. That would save me about fifteen seconds, because at express registers some cashiers have an iPad or smartphone terminal connected to their register counter, rather than waiting to scan up to ten items at one time. Of course this only works out if there’s an express cash register person with available iPad terminal.

Alaska's distilleries can no longer serve mixed drinks to customers, the state agency overseeing alcohol ruled Tuesday.
In a 3-1 vote, the Alcoholic Beverage Control Board decided that distilleries — which make vodka, gin and other liquor products and have no license to dispense beverages — could no longer sell package liquor with their restaurant meals without violating state law amid public safety concerns about the products being mixed incorrectly before being consumed, and because it violated the agency's stated mission to create efficiencies to reduce high costs for retailers.
That prompted some critical backlash.
Gov. Bill Walker said the new policies would be disastrous for small business owners who have focused so much time and effort on expanding their brands.
"These distilleries have already invested $26 million in large facilities, employing hundreds who rely on increased business over summer months to stay in business," he said. "Now how do they eat? How do they get paid?... Back to square one."
Honan said he doesn't have to worry about these regulations because he doesn't sell anything he makes to worrisome customers.
"It's more of those who do sell mixed drinks to be all up in arms about it," he said.

Busan (South Korea) (AFP) - A Korean drama about desperate teens and a movie that exposes the hardships of daily life in the Iranian capital Tehran shared the top prize at Asia's premier film festival on Saturday.
The two grim tales left the audience of 250,000 winner-take-all Busan International Film Festival awestruck, possibly -- but not wholly -- because they compare to much better told (and often more devastating) Hollywood fare. 
Feasting on a record-breaking haul of over three billion Korean Won ($2.6 million) -- the star prize has outgrown previous years -- 200 audience members picked Twister's speeding train saga Ofمدة (Thirst). 
Honoured with another prize -- the grand-standing New Currents award -- was Girl -- a gritty tale about a young Iranian couple facing the daily grind. 
Eclectic journey 
But just about everything was up for grabs on what has become one Korean cinema's most feared -- and feared-of -- stages. 
And some productions have come to Busan to gain weight before becoming US box office draws -- notably James Wan's huge-grossing The Conjuring tandem -- as a third US film wins over cinema judges each day.

An independent report into Queensland's mental health services, released today, details the key weaknesses in the State's model of care, highlighting the negative delays in experiencing treatment.
Greens MP Amy MacMahon said that Queensland experiences some of the longest waiting periods in the country for public mental health services.
"The national standard is two to three months to access care, however, we have seen waiting periods of up to 15 years," she said today.
"What's more concerning is that, even when beds are available, the system fails to utilise them to treat appropriate patients. In some cases patients can languish for years on end in hospital-intensive environments due to lack of appropriate beds."
The State's inadequate mental health system has hindered initiatives to boost suicide intervention on the Sunshine Coast.

Everyone went nuts for Adobe’s “content-aware fill” in Photoshop when it came out. The boring-sounding feature is in fact an incredibly useful tool, essentially an AI-powered clone stamp that intelligently brought in other pieces of the image to replace bad digital paint jobs. It was released up to three years ago as a beta in Photoshop CS5.5, first as an Optional dialog box, and more recently as a standalone tool. We’re still waiting for Apple to free up a spot for a smarter clone stamp with iOS and macOS.
I’m not familiar with digital paint anymore (I mostly just paint with oil), but Pixelmator does make Photoshop-style copies with a reasonable Cloner tool. My first thought was to invite Aaron Ward to write about Photoshop and Pixelmator. Aaron has written some stellar Photoshop features lately for our sister site KeyboardFocus, including a good PS feature guide for iOS. So, Aaron came in to be stroke-punched for this week’s blog post, but his boss got wind of the stroke-punching and re-read him to take a tour about Photoshop for iOS. So Aaron sent me some of his favorite tool tips and gave each of them a practical digital paint application. Take it away Aaron!

The town will now consider changing its animal ordinance.
A Berlin woman is trying to keep her pet goat despite a town ordinance.
A dwarf goat named Benny has been living in a backyard pen at 452 New Britain Road in Berlin for five years, despite the town’s animal control ordinance prohibiting the keeping of domestic, wild, exotic animals in Berlin.
At Tuesday night's animal control advisory committee meeting, three speakers lined up to voice their concerns over the animals' future. One of the speakers was Donna Crowe Minsky, Gail's mother.
"It's a huge pleasure to live up here," said Donna Crowe. "We're pleased to see different animals every once in a while. Gail loves animals. The problem she has is that Gail no longer has her family. If we have to give up [the animals], who's going to have them? It makes us heavy-hearted to have to give up ten animals."
You can never say no to someone who asks you to reconsider an animal control ordinance. Pat Maloney was a gifted experimental musician in the 1970s, until he suddenly stopped playing entirely.
This story starts with an ending.
Pat Maloney passed away in the late summer of 2016. He'd been facing terminal cancer for three years, but suddenly one day he stopped taking treatment, and the disease appeared to be in remission. Just as suddenly though, as he was enjoying a holiday in Portugal with his wife, he suffered a stroke - possibly as a result of dehydration - that fractured his hip. He was taken to hospital, told he would be OK - and a few minutes later died.
His surviving relatives have said he often spoke about the end of his cancer journey as a blessing because he was made aware of his impending demise, and could feel he'd improved things for those he liked. Says his cousin Ted Murphy in a Guardian obituary written by Simon MacDonald: "He was excited by his imminent departure - becoming only the third person he knew to have lived to be 100."

Manifesto is silent on the dangers copyright abuses pose to Internet freedom.
The Campaign for Liberty, a libertarian advocacy group founded by congressman and presidential candidate Ron Paul (R-TX), is gearing up for an "Internet freedom" project that focuses on stamping out Internet piracy. Manifesto is libertarian in outlook, as would be expected from its progenitors, Ron Paul and president Emergent fame, Nick Gillespie.
But galling to supporters of copyright and other IP rights is the organization's failure to mention copyright protection as an important part of Internet freedom. Manifesto's discussions of copyright protection are vague and focus more on the potential costs to Internet freedom posed should fair use be diminished by overly-litigious copyright holders, rather than viewing piracy as an important part of that copyright problem.
Manifesto concedes that piracy undermines copyright enforcement, citing research suggests this could alter "the economic viability of copyrighted digital content." Manifesto also states that piracy could be taken as an excuse to undermine enforcement of civil liberties, singling out British protester Aaron Swartz's alleged piracy as a hacktivist -- a category that Manifesto doesn't define -- to illustrate the point. But Manifesto does little to discourage piracy other than standing up for basic civil liberties in

A British-born sailor presumed lost at sea was not wearing a safety tether when he was knocked overboard during a yacht race, it has been revealed.
John Fisher, who lived in Adelaide, Australia, plunged into the Southern Ocean, around 1.2km (42km) from Williamstown, near Melbourne, on Tuesday night as the finish line to the Regatta to Watch racing was reached off Port Melbourne.
Islington District Court in Sydney has heard he was not connected to a safety tether for some reason during the event, which saw him being pulled underneath one of the other yachts participating.
Although no-one has reported seeing him after he jumped in the water to escape the yacht's propellers, he was found on Wednesday afternoon.
Assistant Crown prosecutor Claire Tyrrell told the court fisherman Nick Craig told crew member Scott Bennet was "absolutely distraught" at finding him just off Bellbird Bay.
Craig told the court Bennet described to the others who fished down to him as being blown out to sea as he was being dragged underneath the yacht. Bennet said: "We thought he was dead"
But Mr Bennet eventually picked him up. "I thought he was more dead than alive," he told police later.

A Canton-based food pantry that feeds hundreds of families across western Wayne County is getting a boost as it heads toward the Thanksgiving holiday.
Open Door Ministry, which feeds about 430 struggling families every week, has been chosen for a food drive by Bay City State Theatre staff and volunteers to benefit The One Harvest campaign run by the Michigan Harmonie Museum Society.
Beginning this week, staff at the State Theatre has recruited about 25 volunteers to hold three different food drives over three weeks leading up to Thanksgiving. Two of the State Theatre volunteers have taught classes to other volunteers to ensure everyone knows the school district's food safety guidelines.
Lauren Baker, who grew up in Birthright Ministries and taught school district a class on recipes, said once people come up to learn about the campaign, they are devoting weeks to The One Harvest drive.
"We want everyone who believes in supporting our community to be part of it," Baker said.
The State Theatre staff plans to match whatever Bay City State Theatre staff and volunteers raise to bring Open Door's goal up to $30,000 -- a goal that was realistic, because the pantry was expecting another box truck to deliver a week's worth of food.
The State Theatre staff has decided to make all donations to The One

A new study by researchers at The Kinsey Institute and the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center has found that the timeless, multicultural tradition of grandmothering might have an unexpected benefit: helping some women temper their hot flashes and night sweats during menopause.
Women who perceived themselves as being good grandmothers reported spending more time doing things to control the sweats, namely staying chilled, relaxing, drinking more fluids, doing more exercise to sweat out to heat, and cheering up to feel good. Eliminating voluminous garbage collection of files

Adding background stream compression to reduce network traffic within HDFS

Analysis: OpenMFG helps fill the void of open-source ERP applications for small and midsized businesses.
For the largest enterprises, access to the source code of their enterprise resource planning applications is a given. The critical nature of ERP, the central position it has in a firm's operations and the large outlays necessary to license and maintain the suites have all added to the demand for source code access. In particular, large firms have preferred to build large, in-house development teams to extend their corporate wide-readiness as opposed to relying solely on third-party add-on applications.
For small and midsize enterprises (SMBs), source-code access has long remained out of the question -- a critical challenge to their ability to truly control or extend the values promised by ERP suites. While IT department limitations have long made third-party consulting firms the logical choice for being added to the source-code base, these SMBs have often striven to limit the amount of third-party sourcing as much as possible. Therefore, source-code access has taken on critical elements --цемσω it would reinforce the firm's long-held perception of the business IT system as being its own to control, right to its core.
Given business expectations of ERP's potential to solve critical business challenges

Former Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, musician Bob Dylan and astronaut John Glenn were among a select group of 13 Americans named by President Obama Thursday as the latest recipients of the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the nation’s highest civilian honor.
The White House said the honor would be given to Albright for her “career of achievement as the nation’s first female secretary of state.” Albright was appointed to that post by President Clinton and was notable for her public displays of passionate opinion: she once told CBS that the United States has “special responsibilities” to promote gender equality around the world, citing UN reports showing that women comprise almost half of the world’s illiterate population; as secretary of state, she said during her trip to El Salvador that “women have always been more critical to the achievement of democracy than men have.” In ceremonies to honor Albright in Washington in September 1997, she said: “We’re all equal in dignity and we all have all the same rights as everybody else. Pierce-Lebin said the raid was conducted as part of an investigation into a homicide and burglary that occurred on Oct. 26, with Troy and other Cap Metro police agencies probing the homicide reported as unrelated to the burglary.
Police did not name the person robbed, but said the robbery was connected to a homicide reported the same day at about 2 p.m. in the Troy Valley development between Fayette Street and Woolsey Avenue.

University Health Network and Vanderbilt Health Affiliated Network are creating a value-based health alliance that will ultimately provide statewide coverage.
A new partnership between doctors and facilities affiliated with University of Tennessee Medical Center and Vanderbilt University Medical Center aims to improve the quality of health care by creating a value-focused model to limit waste and overuse while focusing on better care.
NTUHN includes, as part of its umbrella of care, UT Medical Center, TN Valley Heart, Vertava Health-Western TN and Vertava Health-Dayton. VAMC branches out to hospitals like UnityPI, Woodland Park Garrison and Muscio.

NEW YORK (MarketWatch) — Treasury prices extended their pullback Tuesday, propelling the government debt market to its fourth day of losses in five sessions, after data showed service-sector companies expanded at a faster rate in October.
The Institute for Supply Management reported that data for its non-manufacturing index rose to 56.1 in October from 56.1 in September and from September’s reading of 55.9. A reading above 50 indicates industry expanded.
Gains were narrowed somewhat as applications for unemployment insurance rose by 29,000 to a seasonally adjusted 417,000 to end a three-week decline, the Department of Labor reported.
Government bonds pared losses to end mostly lower as investors searched for more opportunities in the overbought fixed-income market. Yields on the benchmark October contract climbed to above the level reached as part of previous settlement auction results.
And head-to head against the three-year deal, yields remain more in demand.
And yields continue to climb upward Tuesday as investors looked past the ISM data. The three-month deal yields have moved above auction settlement results for today and headed noticeably above auction settlement results tied to settlement Oct. 16, near which time issued Treasury bills will be up for auction.

RICHMOND HILL - A Bryan County inmate temporarily released to be treated for a spider bite has returned to the Southeast Probation Detention Center in Claxton to continue serving his 30-month sentence.
Jack Barfield IV, 33, was taken to Memorial University Medical Center Tuesday after prison guards noticed a small wound on his right leg. They believed the wound was caused by a spider bite.
The facility he was being housed in has exposed concrete walls, which would make it easy for spiders to reside there, so he left to be treated for the bite, said Elwin Martinez, a spokesman with the Georgia Department of Corrections.
Upon doing some research Thursday, Martinez said he learned about New Mexico State University work that concluded spiders often do not survive for more than five to six weeks in a prison environment.
Barfield was taken to a Houston specialist to be treated, and was released Wednesday to serve out the last two weeks of his sentence at another facility in Claxton.
Upon arriving Thursday, he was taken to receive further treatment for the wound because staff at Memorial observed the wound was not healing.
Plans are in place to send him back to Rockdale Correctional Institution in rural Cadiz City, Ky., where he was serving

He led the Scots to victory in the Battle of Bannockburn over the English to finally gain independence from the Empire.
Aside from being deservedly celebrated as a national icon he was a man who always strived to do the right thing, no matter what the upset to him would be.

Lyft has pulled from service all of its on-demand electric bicycles in New York, Washington DC and the San Francisco Bay area after some riders reported issues with the brakes.
"We recently received a small number of reports from riders who experienced stronger than expected brake pressure at their control. We have suspended all e-bike rentals as a precaution," Lyft head of public policy said in a blog post. We plan to relaunch e-bike rentals as soon as we have corrected the safety issues."
Uber spokesperson Nick Pace said the company has no plans to pause e-bike rentals at this time, and spokesperson Meredith D'Amico said Lyft's decision would have no ramifications for Uber's pending business. Both are still working to have their e-bike programs up to speed, having originally planned to reintroduce e-bikes in Q2.

MEXICO CITY (AP) — A man was arrested Monday in the shooting death of a journalist who worked for the newspaper El Heraldo de Chiapas, and authorities were searching for three other people suspected of having ordered the killing.
Luis Alberto Aguilar Gelabert was arrested in Puerto Palomas, Dutch-owned Aruba, and taken to Mexico to be questioned about the shooting death of El Hheraldo photojournalist Ernst Holguin Martinez.
Holguin was shot to death early Sunday as he drove to the office of El Emprendedor in the Guatemalan border town of Villahermosa. The shooting struck Holguin's upper arm as he drove past a restaurant.
His charred BMW sedan was found near a makeshift oil-drum dump about three miles down the paved Highway to Villahermosa, about seven minutes south. His ATM card was taken from him.
Heriberto Jaime Santiago Proctor has been arrested, Mexican and regional news outlets reported, citing statements by Chiapas state authorities.

Remember Microsoft's Bing Cashback program, which refunded a few percentage points (and sometimes more than a few) of online purchases made via the Bing portal? Microsoft shuttered the program last June, but its spirit lives on in the form of FatWallet's Binggetrewardz Amazon gift certificate program -- all completely U.S.-centric of course. Take a trip over to Amazon's site -- preferably from a computer, as tablets can be a bit clunky in this department -- and begin your holiday shopping via Bing, enabling an accounting option to see all products divided up by gift amount (say, buy some predictably cheap MP3 albums and a more expensive Blue Angels recording). Simply purchase your products as you normally would, click the Binggetrewardz gift card option and receive a $5 gift card to Amazon within about 10 to 15 business days. Make sure to contact Bing's cash-back department within seven business days if you receive a negative cash-back refund the first time. Of course PayPal's gift card option doesn't apply to Amazon purchases -- if everything goes as planned -- but your cash can still be used to buy MP3's on Amazon's site.

How do I know when I should exit a trade?
Are there some rules on this that I can follow?
Many traders approach their strategy with one thing in mind: establishing the qualifications for entry. The ‘edge’ if you will. From there, some traders set up automated zones of price to sell at in the hope of protecting their profits to some gain coefficient. As long as the trade does not rise above this zone, the trade continues to be live and awaiting potential gratitude for not being taken out by selling pressure. What a concept!
But as actionable as this may be to some traders, it doesn’t give you much notice. In fact, averaging your profit out two trades before being taken out makes no sense if it lost you double your gain as your objective zone distance was small in relation to price action.
Exits should be more fluid to your trade's emotion. If price has moved lower, no doubt you have exhaled some volatility as to the trade's result. Generally, if a trade has moved down, it has sell pressure. So focus intensely on potentially accepting lower price as long as your risk specifications are met as required by your trade. So long as the trade's benefit to risk has not turned negative, stay in.

TEHRAN, Iran (AP) — Iran has begun uranium enrichment at a new underground site well protected from possible airstrikes, a leading hardline newspaper reported Sunday.
Kayhan daily, which is close to Iran's ruling clerics, said Tehran will start "launching centrifuges," referring to the spinning machine needed to refine crude uranium into the fuel for atomic reactors.
The report came days after a senior Iranian cleric said Iranians should be prepared for strikes on the atomic program as negotiations over its enrichment and other features continue Tuesday.
Iran's atomic energy chief, Ali Akbar Salehi, told reporters Saturday that Tehran could enrich uranium to 20 percent – a figure just a step away from weapons-grade levels. Weapons-made uranium has a 90 percent level of enrichment.
The nuclear negotiations are seeking to end concerns over Iran's enrichment activities as Tehran apparently attempts to secure enough high-grade uranium to make nuclear reactors running on its enriched uranium as well as enough to arm possible long-range missiles.
Iran has said it wants to put its nuclear program on autopilot to ensure atomic energy for the country's productive base but requires the removal of international sanctions to unlock more oil revenues to make the program self-financing.
Iran only has enough uranium to fuel some domestic reactors

agencies at the local, state and federal level all employ marketing professionals in areas including, but not limited to, public relations, property disposal, bond sales and purchasing.
Almost all major government agencies have their own public-relations staff, and in many cases it is a stand-alone department with a public relations or media director and several support staff. Government agency PR departments are responsible for producing news releases, holding press conferences, and generally promoting activities of the agency, such as tourism or encouraging new businesses to move into the area.
Government agencies are constantly buying supplies, equipment and other property and selling off old equipment and property. The departments tasked with disposing of this government property often hire individuals with a background in marketing. Their job is to assist the agency in coming up with creative ways to sell or otherwise dispose of obsolete government property.

the WHO, put processed meats on the top of their “things that cause cancer list”, grouping them alongside tobacco, asbestos and diesel fumes, for which there is “sufficient evidence” of cancer links.
Along the years, there have been many studies that linked processed and red meats with cancer (especially bowel cancer), but there were always some doubts floating about. Now, the 22-member panel analyzed animal experiments, studies of human diet and health, and cell mechanisms that could lead from these meats to cancer.
“These findings further support current public health recommendations to limit intake of meat,” Dr. Christopher Wild, who directs IARC, said in a statement.
The decision wasn’t unanimous though, and a “probably” still crept in to the report. Many studies show the links, both in populations of people and in tests that show how eating these foods can cause cancer, the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) said in its report, released in the Lancet medical journal.

“We have already done a lot of deficit reduction,” he said in an interview on NBC. Lew spoke on four TV talk shows, setting out Obama’s priorities ahead of an expected showdown this fall.
By early November, Congress must raise the legal limit on the country’s borrowing authority or risk an unprecedented default on the government’s debt.
A debt ceiling showdown in August 2011 between Obama and congressional Republicans sparked wild stock market swings and cost the United States its top-tier AAA credit rating.
“We need to get the debt limit extended in a way that doesn’t create a crisis,” Lew said.
Republicans see the debt ceiling as the their best leverage in winning a deal with Obama that would cut federal government spending to lower the deficit.

of diarrhea. There are also some foods to avoid when dealing with a bout of diarrhea, and some additional home care tips to consider.
Anyone who is experiencing persistent diarrhea should see a doctor, as a person may become dehydrated over time.
Diarrhea is a bowel movement that is more liquid than solid or has a loose texture. It is a common problem and may occur a couple of times each year. Diarrhea will usually last no more than 3 days.
Soft, bland foods, such as toast, will help to absorb excess water and ease the symptoms of diarrhea.
People with chronic digestive conditions, such as irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) or Crohn's disease, may experience diarrhea more regularly.
A person's diet is crucial if they are experiencing diarrhea. Some foods might help relieve symptoms of diarrhea while eating other foods can make diarrhea worse.
While recovering from diarrhea, a person should eat bland, simple foods that are easy to digest and will help absorb some water from

On Valentine’s Day 2007, Lynn Blake was embarking on a new job in Vail Village when she had a rude awakening. The 27-year-old suffered sudden cardiac arrest. Fortunately for her, someone trained in CPR stepped forward and kept her heart beating until emergency personnel arrived with a defibrillator. If someone dropped in front of you unconscious, with no notable pulse, would you know what to do? Some 325,000 people die every year of sudden cardiac arrest (SCA) in the United States. And, contrary to popular belief, it strikes people of all ages. “I did not know a thing about cardiac arrest. I didn’t know what it was,” Blake said. Now she knows firsthand about sudden cardiac arrest. The more she found out, the more she wondered why more people weren’t educated about SCA, the leading causes of death in the U.S. Just a few months after Blake’s sudden cardiac

two American women die of pregnancy-related causes every day may come as a surprise.
According to the World Bank, The US ranks 50th in maternal mortality globally - falling behind every other industrialised nation. A woman in the US is as likely to suffer a maternal death as a woman in sanctions-hit Iran, and four times as likely as a woman in Germany.
"It is a preventable health issue," said Amnesty International's Rachel Ward. "It isn't something that we're waiting for a cure for. We’re waiting for political will."
What's worse is that US maternal mortality rates may actually be on the rise. Eugene Declercq, of Boston University's School of Public Health, produced a short film named Birth by the numbers, discussing maternal mortality in the US. In a 2013 follow-up report, he noted how mortality rates in other industrialised nations had declined - but in the US, it increased by 30 percent in the first decade of the new millennium.

It’s not the food—the grub is OK, if not exactly slimming; it’s the gas generators powering the carts. Most food carts run off a diesel generator that’s designed to run only a few hours. Vendors run them for stretches of up to 14 hours, leading to a high output of greenhouse-gas emissions such as carbon monoxide, nitrous oxide, and particulate matter. You can see the smoke with the naked eye, but the hard facts are even more frightening: The research and consulting firm Energy Vision found that each cart produces the same amount of nitrous oxide as 186 cars on the road.

In its milestone report, “The Limits to Growth”, published in 1972, the Club of Rome warned that the human ecological footprint had grown dangerously quickly from 1900 to 1972. Shortly thereafter, the warning proved to be prophetic: by 1986 the human ecological footprint had overshot the carrying capacity of the Earth. At current production and consumption levels, we need 1.5 planets to survive; if everyone lived like a U.S. citizen, we would need five planets.
Land, water and biodiversity continue to decline. Global CO2 emissions are on the rise. The oceans are warming and the sea level is rising continuously. Forest cover has decreased by 300 million hectares since 1990.

The study was conducted among some 350 patients who reported issues like headaches, eyesight changes and similar vision problems in emergency rooms.
The study also included the inner-eye photos taken by the ER staff using an ocular camera.
Then the study team assessed the response of two ophthalmologists who viewed and rated the pictures on a desktop PC and did the same on an iPhone.
The results of the study, published in the Archives of Ophthalmology, show that the doctors found the iPhone images good or better than desktop images and rated them high.
While one ophthalmologist felt 53 pictures were of the same quality, he found 46 better on iPhone and just one was better on PC.
For the other ophthalmologist who participated in the study, 56 were of equal quality, while 42 were better on iPhone leaving only two better on PC.

many celebrated breakthroughs were initially met with scorn and ridicule. We've compiled 11 such world-famous ideas from the history of science and technology. The temptation, of course, is to include those ideas that were scorned and should have stayed scorned. The Star Wars prequels, say. But we're trying to run a classy operation here.
Heliocentrism Galileo Galilei, sometimes called the Father of Modern Science, was among the first and most famous to pay a price for his crazy scientific ideas. Galileo publicly promoted the Copernican concept of heliocentrism -- that the Earth revolves around the Sun -- back when the Church and even most fellow mathematicians held to geocentric model. Unfortunately, in 17th century Rome, such radical ideas were quite literally heresy. Galileo was forced to recant and spend the rest of his life under house arrest.

Vista requires premium content like high-definition movies to be degraded in quality when sent to high-quality outputs, so users are seeing status codes that say "graphics OPM resolution too high." Gutmann calls this "probably the most bizarre status code ever."

, warm growing season and grow best when planted outdoors as seedlings. You can enjoy fresh peppers or grow them to dry and use in your favorite dishes even if you do not have room for an outdoor garden. You can grow jalapenos in containers indoors and outdoors or grow them hydroponically.
You can grow jalapenos outdoors, starting two to three weeks after the last spring frost. Jalapenos require full sun, which is at least six hours of sun daily, and well-drained soil amended with organic matter. The proper pH level for jalapenos is 6.0 to 6.8, so to adjust, add limestone if the pH is low and peat moss if it is higher than 6.8. experiments fail. The effect you're looking for might not even occur, meaning that a null result should always be a possible outcome you're prepared for. When that happens, the experiment is often dismissed as a failure, even though you never would have known the results without performing it.
Yet, every once in a while, the apparatus that you build might be sensitive to something else entirely. When you do science in a new way, at a new sensitivity, or under new, unique conditions, that's often where the most surprising, serendipitous discoveries are made. In 1987, a failed experiment for detecting proton decay detected neutrinos, for the first time, from beyond not only our Solar System, but from outside of the Milky Way. This is how neutrino astronomy was born.
The conversion of a neutron to a proton, an electron, and an anti-electron neutrino is how Pauli hypothesized resolving the energy non-conservation problem in beta decay.

National Weather Service also says the region is “abnormally dry,” the first stage of its drought-measurement scale.
No, climate change hasn’t driven weather folks crazy. The solution to the puzzle is that there are droughts and then there are droughts.
“There is a time lapse in how different systems respond to current conditions,” is how Richard Kiah, chief of Hydrologic Network Operations for the regional office of the U.S. Geological Survey, puts it.
In laymen’s terms: When wet weather appears, as it did in July, after a long stretch of very dry weather like we had this spring, the grass starts growing pretty quickly but it takes longer to fill up the aquifers that our wells depend on. A drought above ground might end, might even give way to flooding, while drought lingers below ground.
That’s roughly what we’re seeing now, although thankfully the drought and flooding have been minor compared to other parts of the country.

azakhstan's new interim president was sworn in Wednesday following the shock resignation of the country's long-time ruler and in his first official act renamed the capital after his predecessor.
Kassym-Jomart Tokayev took office in a pomp-filled ceremony less than 24 hours after Nursultan Nazarbayev, the only leader an independent Kazakhstan had ever known, suddenly announced he was stepping down.
Tokayev immediately proposed changing the name of the Central Asian nation's capital from Astana to Nursultan, or "Sultan of Light" in Kazakh, and parliament approved the change within hours.
The senate also appointed Nazarbayev's eldest daughter Dariga Nazarbayeva as speaker, setting her up as a potential contender to succeed her father.
Tokayev, 65, will serve out the rest of Nazarbayev's mandate until elections due in April next year, though the former president retains significant powers in the country he ruled for nearly three decades.

Is Renting an Apartment with Bad Credit Possible?
One way to solve this problem is to bypass the credit issue entirely. Many privately-owned homes and apartment buildings do not look at credit, preferring to find tenants with good references from previous landlords. You can find advertisements for privately-owned rentals in the classified section of your newspaper, on the internet at sites like Craig's List and Rental.com, as well as through local real estate agents.
Many local homeowners and condo owners rent their houses because they are having trouble selling them in the current real estate market, so you may be able to find a very nice property at a reasonable rate, provided you are a good tenant and are willing to keep the place clean and in order.

Just over two years ago the church started demolition on the 1928 chapel. Since then, the space has sat vacant.
A new building will now be built that will expand the current property by 25,000 square feet. The new building will include children’s classrooms, a children’s worship area, a new nursery, and new church offices. The building will be used for not just Sunday but for the church’s Mother’s Day Out program.
The project will also include the building of “The Reich Chandler Great Hall” which will connect the new education building and sanctuary.
Reich Chandler was a church member and the son of George and Martha Chandler. After graduating from Lufkin High School in 1985, he went to Baylor University to study law. Chandler practiced law in Houston and Dallas before returning home to practice with his father.
Sadly after battling cancer for 15 months, Chandler died in 2006 at the age of 39.
The Chandler family was in attendance.

Bishop and Gerald Holland sued the state in October 2007, claiming that the lethal-injection procedure constituted cruel and unusual punishment. Berry and Bishop have been executed since the filing.
The 5th Circuit said their complaint is time-barred, because the procedure could be challenged as early as 1997, and the state never hid its lethal-injection procedure. The limitation period for the inmates’ actions accrues from the date of their convictions and sentencing, the court ruled, or when the state changes its execution procedure. The plaintiffs’ actions accrued between 1998 and 1999.
When the state moved for summary judgment based on the three-year statute of limitations, the inmates argued that it did not apply because their lawsuit sought an injunction, not damages. The plaintiffs also argued that even if the statute of limitations applied, the action did not accrue before the Supreme Court’s rulings in Hill v. McDonough (2006) and Baze v. Rees (2008).

ylie and Shahmir Sanni are calling for the Electoral Commission to investigate allegations that the group exceeded campaign spending limits. In a 50-page dossier, the lawyers claim Vote Leave circumvented the limit by donating £625,000 ($885,000) to pro-Brexit student BeLeave group, to which it was closely linked.
The donation, however, was allegedly used for Vote Leave, bringing its total spending over the legal limit of £7 million ($9.9 million), breaching electoral law.
The dossier is largely based on witness statements by former Cambridge Analytica employee Wylie, and Sanni – a volunteer who worked at both Vote Leave and BeLeave. Speaking to journalists on Monday, Wylie said the dossier contains evidence undermining the legitimacy of the EU referendum result, which could prompt a new one to be held. Vote Leave has strongly denied any wrongdoing and said the £625,000 donated to BeLeave in the final days of the 2016 campaign was within the rules.

There's no need to go bald any more.
Baldness is a complex polygenic trait: up to five genes are involved, and it is the interplay between these genes, not unlike the interaction between the cards in a poker hand, that determine the specifics of male pattern hair loss.
So, what are the treatment options?
Finasteride is a Therapeutic Goods Administration-approved drug that dermatologists and general practitioners have been prescribing to treat hair loss for about 15 years.
It works by stopping the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone in the prostate, by blocking an enzyme called 5-alpha reductase.
You'll need a prescription for finasteride, and your doctor will explain the benefits and risks of the drug before you decide to proceed.
The benefits are clear: men who start taking daily finasteride at the first signs of hair loss will

Unfortunately, there are no easy answers. Who is the “I” who decided to have fish and chips? Your gut reaction might tell you that you are a conscious entity controlling your physical body. But that physical body includes the brain that generates your consciousness. There is no splitting the two.
Metaphysics special: What is consciousness?
We do know that any sense we have of being in control of our actions is, to some extent, an illusion. In particular, neuroscientist Benjamin Libet showed in the 1980s that mechanisms within the brain initiate actions long before that brain’s owner is aware of deciding to perform them.

For those coming in late, HGST is the mashup of Hitachi's former disk business with IBM's former disk business. Western Digital bought HGST a couple of years ago, and is keeping the respected HGST brand alive.
Skyera was a late-entry into the all-flash array market that HGST bought last year. While it wasn't clear if Skyera had shipped a v1.0 product, the buy was surprising because, traditionally, drive vendors have not competed with their storage system customers.
But the reasons for that traditional non-compete stance are fading. All major drive buyers want a 2nd source, but with only 2.5 drive vendors - WD, Seagate and Toshiba - drive buyers can't threaten to walk away.

In this sense, the ocean has acted as a buffer to slow down the greenhouse gas accumulation in the atmosphere and, thus, global warming. However, this process also increases the acidity of seawater and can affect the health of marine organisms and the ocean ecosystem.
New research by University of Delaware oceanographer Wei-Jun Cai and colleagues at Université Libre de Bruxelles, Texas A&M University-Corpus Christi, University of Hawaii at Manoa and ETH Zurich, now reveals that the water over the continental shelves is shouldering a larger portion of the load, taking up more and more of this atmospheric carbon dioxide.
The study findings, published in Nature Communications on Wednesday, Jan. 31, may have important implications for scientists focused on understanding the global carbon budget.

You have reason to be cautious with pain relievers. greatest achievements in physics in the last century: the discovery last week of the elusive Higgs boson – the God particle. Although Higgs proposed the theory of the particle nearly 50 years ago, behind the scenes, dozens of physicists from Scotland played a vital role in the experiments which led to the identification of the Higgs boson – a particle which holds the key to explaining how matter attains its mass, and how the universe works at its most fundamental level.
The discovery awaits full endorsement from the scientific community.
Around 50 academics, researchers, technicians and postgraduate students from both Glasgow and Edinburgh universities were part of the Atlas experiment team at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) in Cern, Switzerland, which announced the breakthrough on Wednesday.
Here we talk to some of those Scottish scientists about their work on the Atlas experiment and their thoughts on the significance of the likely discovery of the Higgs Boson particle.

Researchers at Missouri University of Science and Technology under engineering professor Reza Zoughi have developed a patented device that can show the inner structures of objects in real time by using millimeter and microwave signals.
Potential applications include the detection of cancerous skin cells, termite damage to buildings, or concealed weapons at secure zones like airports.
The tech could also be used for finding "defects in thermal insulating materials that are found in spacecraft heat insulating foam and tiles, space habitat structures, aircraft radomes and composite-strengthened concrete bridge members," Zoughi was quoted as saying in a release.
The prototype camera has been in development for several years--check out the vid below, from 2009.
In its current form, objects have to be placed between a transmitter for the microwave radiation and a collector. It can run for several hours on a laptop-size battery.

groundwork for difficult meetings this week in which she will try to unite a divided cabinet behind her vision for post-Brexit Britain.
May was applauded by European Union leaders in Brussels on Friday after securing an agreement to move previously-deadlocked talks forward onto the topic of interim and long-term trading arrangements.
The progress has gone some way to easing concerns of businesses and investors who fear Britain could crash out of the bloc without an exit deal, or that May's fragile government could collapse under the pressure of delivering Brexit.
"Amid all the noise, we are getting on with the job," May wrote in the Sunday Telegraph. "My message today is very clear: we will not be derailed from this fundamental duty to deliver the democratic will of the British people."
But May can expect some difficult exchanges this week when she and senior ministers discuss the so-called "end state" of the Brexit negotiations for the first time since Britain voted to leave the EU in a referendum in June 2016.

week after a 7.0-magnitude earthquake flattened many parts of the city and killed tens of thousands.

More U.N. convoys were seen moving through the city than in previous days, and so could vehicles for large nongovernmental organizations.

Even if you didn't participate in the monthlong-ish meme by compiling your own list of "25 Things," you probably delighted in/loathed reading the all-about-me rosters of your pals. Missing those halcyon days?
In recent weeks we've seen the flipside of the "25 Things List" gaining traction on the ol' FB: the "How Well Do You Know *Your Name Here*?" quiz.
In other words, now our friends aren't offering us tidbits of their lives; they are asking us to report back to them on our knowledge of their personal tidbits.
Are we up to the challenge, America? So far, we're seeing scores of 40 to 50 percent coming back as friends take other friends' tests. "Hmm" might sum it up best. Just hmm.
Maybe the questions are too difficult? Too focused on minutia?
